docs.title: CPH-NG Documentation
docs.text: Welcome to the CPH-NG documentation! This comprehensive guide covers everything you need to know about using CPH-NG for competitive programming.

docs.title: For New Users
docs.text:
Start here if you're new to CPH-NG:

  1. Overview - Learn what CPH-NG is and its key features
  2. Quick Start - Get up and running in minutes
  3. FAQ - Common questions and answers

docs.title: For Regular Users
docs.text:
Explore features and customize your experience:

  1. Feature Guide - Comprehensive guide to all features (20KB+)
  2. Configuration - Complete settings reference (21KB+)
  3. Modules - Additional functionality

docs.title: For Contributors
docs.text:
Learn about the project:

  1. About - Project information and contributing guidelines

docs.title: 🌍 Languages
docs.text:
Documentation is available in:

  • English (default)
  • 简体中文 (Chinese Simplified)

Switch languages using the language selector in the documentation site.

docs.title: Features (21 Individual Pages)
docs.text:
Each feature has a dedicated page with:

Problem Management (4 pages): - Create Problem - Initialize new competitive programming problem - Import Problem - Import from CPH format - Edit Problem - Modify metadata, limits, SPJ, interactor - Delete Problem - Remove problem from workspace

Test Case Management (6 pages): - Add Test Case - Manual single case creation - Load Test Cases - Bulk import from files/folders - Edit Test Case - Modify input and answer data - Delete Test Case - Remove specific test case - Toggle File/Inline - Switch data storage mode - Compare Output - Visual diff of actual vs expected

Running and Testing (4 pages): - Run Single Test - Execute one test case - Run All Tests - Execute all sequentially - Stop Execution - Terminate running tests - Clear Results - Reset execution results

Advanced Features (4 pages): - Brute Force Compare - Find edge cases automatically - Special Judge - Custom checker programs - Interactive Problems - Support for interactive problems - Submit to Codeforces - Direct submission

Integration (2 pages): - Competitive Companion - Browser extension integration - CPH Import - Import from original CPH

Each page includes: UI interaction methods, internal operation with source code references, configuration options, error handling, workflow examples.

docs.title: Configuration Reference (10 Categories)
docs.text:
Comprehensive settings documentation organized by category:

  1. Basic Settings - UI and folder selection
  2. Compilation Settings - Compilers for C/C++/Java
  3. Runner Settings - Execution and resource measurement
  4. Comparing Settings - Output comparison behavior
  5. Brute Force Settings - Generator and brute force timeouts
  6. Problem Settings - Defaults and file paths
  7. Cache Settings - Compilation cache management
  8. CPH Compatibility - Original CPH integration
  9. Companion Settings - Browser extension config
  10. Sidebar Settings - UI customization

Includes: Path variable reference, configuration examples, source code references

docs.title: FAQ
docs.text: Comprehensive Q&A covering: - General questions and installation - Feature usage and configuration - Advanced features - Troubleshooting - Getting help

docs.title: 🤝 Contributing to Documentation
docs.text: We welcome documentation improvements! Here's how to help:

docs.title: Fixing Issues
docs.text:
1. Found a typo or error? Edit the markdown file directly
  2. Submit a pull request with your fix
  3. See DOCUMENTATION_STRUCTURE.md for style guidelines

docs.title: Adding Content
docs.text:
1. Check if the content fits existing pages
  2. If creating a new page, update mkdocs.yml navigation
  3. Add both English and Chinese versions
  4. Include cross-references to related content
  5. Test the build before submitting

docs.text:

When updating English content, please update Chinese translations too, or note that translations need updating in your PR.

docs.title: CPH-NG Documentation Structure
docs.text: This document describes the structure and organization of the CPH-NG documentation.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: The documentation is built using MkDocs with the Material theme, supporting both English and Chinese (Simplified) versions.

docs.title: 1. Overview (index.en.md / index.zh.md)
docs.text:
Purpose: Landing page introducing CPH-NG

Content: - Project introduction - Key features overview - Quick links to other documentation sections - Installation instructions

Target Audience: New users discovering CPH-NG

docs.title: 2. Quick Start (quickStart.md)
docs.text:
Purpose: Get users started quickly

Content: - Installation instructions - Creating first problem - Adding test cases - Running tests - Next steps with links to detailed guides

Target Audience: New users ready to start using CPH-NG

docs.title: 3. Features (features/ folder with 21 pages)
docs.text:
Purpose: Individual detailed documentation for each feature

Structure: Each feature has its own page following unified format:

  • Overview - Purpose and functionality
  • UI Interaction - Triggering methods, prerequisites, UI components
  • Internal Operation - Code flow with source file:line references
  • Configuration Options - Related settings that affect behavior
  • Error Handling - Common errors and solutions
  • Workflow Examples - Practical usage scenarios
  • Related Features - Links to connected functionality
  • Technical Details - Dependencies, data structures, source references

Organization: - features/index.md - Navigation hub - Problem Management/ - Create, Import, Edit, Delete - Test Case Management/ - Add, Load, Edit, Delete, Toggle, Compare - Running and Testing/ - Run Single, Run All, Stop, Clear - Advanced Features/ - Brute Force, SPJ, Interactive, Submit - Integration/ - Competitive Companion, CPH Import

Target Audience: Users needing detailed feature understanding with code references

docs.title: 4. Configuration (configuration/ folder)
docs.text:
Purpose: Settings reference organized by category

Structure: - configuration/index.md - Overview and navigation - Lists all 10 setting categories - Path variables reference table - Configuration examples (competitive, debug, performance) - Source code references

Planned Individual Pages (to be created): - basic.md - Basic extension settings - compilation.md - Compiler configuration - runner.md - Execution settings - comparing.md - Output comparison - brute-force.md - BF compare settings - problem.md - Problem defaults and paths - cache.md - Cache management - cph-compat.md - CPH compatibility - companion.md - Browser extension integration - sidebar.md - UI customization

Target Audience: Users customizing CPH-NG behavior

docs.title: 5. Modules (modules.md)
docs.text:
Purpose: Additional features and workflows

Content: - Compare with answer - Data display toggles - Load samples from files/folders - Edit problem metadata - Elapsed time tracking - Delete problem - Load from embedded data - Import from CPH - Special Judge

Target Audience: Users exploring specific functionality

docs.title: 6. FAQ (faq.md / faq.zh.md)
docs.text:
Purpose: Answer common questions

Content organized by category: - General Questions - Installation & Setup - Using CPH-NG - Advanced Features - Troubleshooting - Getting Help - Additional Resources

Target Audience: Users with specific questions or issues

docs.title: 7. About (about.md)
docs.text:
Purpose: Project information and contribution guidelines

Content: - About the project - Contributing guidelines - License information

Target Audience: Contributors and users wanting to learn more about the project

docs.title: Navigation Structure
docs.text:
The documentation uses a tab-based navigation in this order:

  1. Overview
  2. Quick Start
  3. Feature Guide
  4. Configuration
  5. Modules
  6. FAQ
  7. About

This order follows a typical user journey from discovery to advanced usage.

docs.title: Cross-Referencing Strategy
docs.text:
Documentation pages are extensively cross-referenced:

  • Overview → Quick Start, Feature Guide, Configuration, FAQ
  • Quick Start → Feature Guide, Configuration
  • Feature Guide → Configuration (specific settings for each feature)
  • Modules → Feature Guide (detailed explanations), Configuration
  • FAQ → All other pages as needed

docs.title: Markdown Extensions
docs.text:
The documentation uses these MkDocs Material extensions:

  • Admonitions (!!! syntax) for tips, notes, warnings
  • Code highlighting with copy buttons
  • Tables for structured information
  • Emoji for visual enhancement
  • Tabbed content for alternative options
  • Table of contents with deep linking

docs.title: Image Organization
docs.text:
All images are stored in docs/images/ and referenced relatively:

![Description](images/imagename.png)

Images show actual UI elements and workflows to help users understand features visually.

docs.text:
• English (default): *.en.md or *.md (without suffix)
  • Chinese (Simplified): *.zh.md

As of this documentation:

docs.title: Translation Guidelines
docs.text:
When translating:

  1. Maintain the same structure and headings
  2. Translate content while preserving technical terms appropriately
  3. Update cross-references to point to corresponding translated pages
  4. Keep code examples and configuration samples in English
  5. Translate UI element names consistently

mkdocs serve

Visit http://localhost:8000 to preview changes in real-time.

mkdocs build

Generates static site in site/ directory.

mkdocs build --strict

Treats warnings as errors.

docs.title: Adding a New Page
docs.text:
1. Create the markdown file in docs/
  2. Create translated versions (e.g., page.en.md, page.zh.md)
  3. Add to nav section in mkdocs.yml
  4. Add cross-references from related pages
  5. Test the build locally

docs.title: Updating Existing Content
docs.text:
1. Make changes to the markdown file
  2. Update translated versions
  3. Update cross-references if structure changed
  4. Verify all links still work
  5. Test the build

docs.title: Style Guidelines
docs.text:
1. Headings: Use sentence case, not title case
  2. Code blocks: Always specify language for syntax highlighting
  3. Links: Use relative paths, not absolute URLs for internal pages
  4. Admonitions: Use appropriate types (tip, note, warning, info)
  5. Images: Include descriptive alt text
  6. Lists: Use - for unordered lists, numbers for ordered

docs.title: Writing Style
docs.text:
1. Be concise: Get to the point quickly
  2. Be specific: Include exact steps, not vague instructions
  3. Be helpful: Explain why, not just what
  4. Use examples: Show concrete usage
  5. Think workflow: Organize by how users work, not by code structure

docs.title: Regular Tasks
docs.text:
• Update screenshots when UI changes
  • Add new features to Feature Guide and Configuration Reference
  • Update FAQ with common questions from issues
  • Verify all links after refactoring
  • Keep translations synchronized

docs.title: Quality Checks
docs.text:
Before committing documentation changes:

  1. ✅ Run mkdocs build to verify it builds
  2. ✅ Check for broken internal links
  3. ✅ Verify images display correctly
  4. ✅ Test cross-references
  5. ✅ Review in both English and Chinese

docs.title: What is CPH-NG?
docs.text:
CPH-NG (Competitive Programming Helper - Next Generation) is a VS Code extension for competitive programming. It helps you compile, run, and judge your solutions locally with test cases imported from online judges or created manually.

See the Overview for more information.

docs.title: How is CPH-NG different from the original CPH?
docs.text:
CPH-NG is a complete rewrite with many enhancements:

  • More judging statuses (21 vs 3)
  • Compilation caching for faster testing
  • Support for loading test cases from files and folders
  • Special Judge (SPJ) and interactive problem support
  • Brute force comparison
  • Better memory management

See the comparison table in the README.

docs.title: What languages does CPH-NG support?
docs.text:
Currently, CPH-NG supports:

  • C++ (recommended for competitive programming)
  • C
  • Java

More languages may be added in future releases.

docs.title: Where can I download CPH-NG?
docs.text:
Install directly from VS Code:

  1. Open VS Code
  2. Go to Extensions (Ctrl/Cmd+Shift+X)
  3. Search for "CPH NG"
  4. Click Install

Or use this direct link: Install CPH-NG

docs.title: How do I configure my compiler?
docs.text:
1. Open VS Code Settings (Ctrl/Cmd+,)
  2. Search for "cph-ng compilation"
  3. Configure compiler paths and flags

See Compilation Settings for details.

docs.title: Can I use a custom code template?
docs.text:
Yes! Set the template file path in settings:

{
  "cph-ng.problem.templateFile": "/path/to/your/template.cpp"
}

See Problem Settings for more options.

docs.title: How do I create a new problem?
docs.text:
Three ways:

  1. Click "CREATE" in the sidebar
  2. Use command palette: CPH-NG: Create Problem
  3. Use keyboard shortcut: Ctrl+Alt+B (or Cmd+Alt+B on macOS)

See Quick Start for details.

docs.title: How do I import problems from online judges?
docs.text:
1. Install the Competitive Companion browser extension
  2. Go to a problem on a supported judge (Codeforces, AtCoder, etc.)
  3. Click the Competitive Companion icon
  4. CPH-NG will automatically create the problem with test cases

See Feature Guide - Competitive Companion for configuration options.

docs.title: How do I load test cases from files?
docs.text:
1. Click the folder icon in the problem panel
  2. Choose "Load from zip file" or "Load from folder"
  3. Select your file/folder
  4. Choose which test cases to import

CPH-NG automatically matches .in files with .out/.ans files by name.

See Feature Guide - Loading from Files for details.

docs.title: Why is my program not compiling?
docs.text:
Common issues:

  1. Compiler not found: Check compiler path in settings
  2. Compilation timeout: Increase timeout in Compilation Settings
  3. Syntax errors: Check the compilation output panel

docs.title: Why is my solution getting TLE when it should pass?
docs.text:
Possible reasons:

  1. Slow machine: Increase timeAddition in Runner Settings
  2. Actual infinite loop: Review your code logic
  3. Time limit too strict: Edit problem metadata to increase time limit

docs.title: How do I use Special Judge?
docs.text:
1. Write a checker program (using testlib.h or custom)
  2. Compile your checker
  3. Click the pen icon to edit problem metadata
  4. Click "Choose Checker" and select your compiled checker

See Feature Guide - Special Judge for requirements and examples.

docs.title: What is brute force comparison?
docs.text:
Brute force comparison helps find edge cases by:

  1. Generating random test inputs
  2. Running both your optimized solution and a brute force reference
  3. Comparing outputs until they differ
  4. Saving the failing case as a test case

See Feature Guide - Brute Force Comparison for setup instructions.

docs.title: How does compilation caching work?
docs.text:
CPH-NG calculates a hash of your source code and compiler settings. If nothing changed since the last compilation, it reuses the cached binary, saving time.

This is automatic and requires no configuration.

docs.title: Can I customize the folder where problems are stored?
docs.text:
Yes! Configure the path pattern in settings:

{
  "cph-ng.problem.problemFilePath": "${workspace}/.cph-ng/${basename}.bin"
}

See Problem Settings for available variables.

docs.title: How do I hide certain judging statuses?
docs.text:
Configure hidden statuses in settings:

{
  "cph-ng.sidebar.hiddenStatuses": ["WT", "FC", "CP", "CPD"]
}

See Sidebar Settings for the full list of status codes.

docs.title: The sidebar panel is not showing
docs.text:
1. Check if the CPH-NG icon is in your activity bar
  2. Click the icon to open the panel
  3. If still not showing, try reloading VS Code (Ctrl/Cmd+Shift+P → "Developer: Reload Window")

docs.title: Test cases are not running
docs.text:
1. Make sure the file is saved
  2. Check if compilation succeeded
  3. Look for errors in the compilation output panel
  4. Verify compiler settings are correct

docs.title: Memory measurements are not accurate
docs.text:
Enable the advanced runner:

{
  "cph-ng.runner.useRunner": true
}

Note: May require additional system permissions.

See Runner Settings for details.

docs.title: Output is too large and not showing
docs.text:
Large outputs are automatically saved to files. You can:

  1. Click the filename to view the content
  2. Toggle between file and inline display using the file icon
  3. Adjust the threshold in Runner Settings

docs.title: I'm getting permission errors on Linux/macOS
docs.text:
Some features may require:

  1. Executable permissions on your compiler
  2. Write permissions in the cache directory
  3. Permissions to create files in your workspace

Check your system permissions and file ownership.

docs.title: Where can I report bugs?
docs.text:
Report bugs on GitHub Issues.

Please include:

  • Your OS and VS Code version
  • CPH-NG version
  • Steps to reproduce
  • Error messages or screenshots

docs.title: Where can I request features?
docs.text: Feature requests are welcome on GitHub Discussions.

docs.title: How can I contribute?
docs.text: Contributions are welcome! See the About page for information on how to contribute.

docs.text: CPH-NG is open source: GitHub Repository

docs.title: CPH-NG
docs.text:
CPH-NG (Competitive Programming Helper - Next Generation) is a Visual Studio Code (VS Code) extension specifically developed for competitive programming.

CPH-NG empowers users to conveniently and efficiently compile, run, and judge their programs directly within the VS Code environment.

Warning

Until now, CPH NG supports C++ and Java only.

docs.title: What is CPH-NG?
docs.text: CPH-NG is the next generation of the Competitive Programming Helper, providing a comprehensive solution for competitive programmers working in VS Code. Whether you're practicing on online judges or working on your own problems, CPH-NG streamlines your workflow from problem creation to submission.

docs.title: 🎯 Intelligent Test Data Management
docs.text:
Offers multiple flexible ways to import test data:

  • Import from Competitive Companion browser extension
  • Load from zip files or directories
  • Manually create test cases
  • Import from CPH format
  • Load from embedded data in source files

docs.title: ⚡ Smart Compilation System
docs.text:
CPH-NG features an intelligent compilation system that:

  • Detects file changes and only recompiles when necessary
  • Caches compiled binaries for faster testing
  • Supports custom compiler flags and optimization levels
  • Provides clear compilation error messages
  • Supports compilation hooks and wrappers

docs.title: 📊 Comprehensive Judging System
docs.text:
CPH-NG supports 21 distinct judging statuses:

  • AC (Accepted) - Your solution is correct
  • PC (Partially Correct) - Some test cases passed
  • PE (Presentation Error) - Output format is incorrect
  • WA (Wrong Answer) - Incorrect output
  • TLE (Time Limit Exceeded) - Execution took too long
  • MLE (Memory Limit Exceeded) - Used too much memory
  • OLE (Output Limit Exceeded) - Generated too much output
  • RE (Runtime Error) - Program crashed during execution
  • RF (Restricted Function) - Used forbidden system calls
  • CE (Compilation Error) - Failed to compile
  • SE (System Error) - Internal judging error
  • And more...

docs.title: 🎓 Special Judge Support
docs.text:
CPH-NG fully supports:

  • Special Judge (SPJ) programs using testlib.h or custom checkers
  • Interactive problems with custom interactors
  • Flexible problem verification for non-standard output formats

docs.title: 🔄 Advanced Features
docs.text:
• Brute Force Comparison: Test your optimized solution against a brute force reference
  • File/Inline Toggle: Switch between inline data and external files for large test cases
  • Elapsed Time Tracking: Monitor how long you've been working on a problem
  • Answer Comparison View: Visual diff for wrong answers
  • Result Persistence: Keep track of your test results across sessions

docs.text:

docs.title: Installation
docs.text:
Install CPH-NG directly from the Visual Studio Code Marketplace:

Install CPH-NG

Or search for "CPH NG" in the VS Code Extensions panel.

docs.title: Modules
docs.text:
This page covers additional modules and features. For the basic operations—creating a problem, adding test cases, and running tests, please see Quick Start.

For a comprehensive guide with detailed explanations of how each feature works, see the Feature Guide.

Configuration

All features can be customized through Configuration Settings.

docs.title: Compare with answer
docs.text:
If a test case returns a WA (Wrong Answer), you can view the comparison against the correct answer by clicking the leftmost button in the output area.

If you find that the current expected answer for a test case is incorrect, you can reset it by clicking on the current answer field.

Configuration

You can customize comparison behavior in Comparing Settings, such as treating Presentation Error as Accepted or ignoring stderr output.

docs.title: Data Display Toggles: File & Inline
docs.text:
Click the Toggle to file button to save the data to an external file.

Conversely, if the data is currently displayed as a file, clicking this button will toggle it to inline view.

If the file you are attempting to toggle to inline is too large, CPH-NG will display a warning reminder.

docs.title: Load samples from files&folder
docs.text:
The second button from the left allows you to load samples from zipped files or directories.

You have the flexibility to choose the source location for your test cases.

If you choose to load from zipped file or from a folder, you have to choose the specific file or folder.

Finally, you must confirm which specific test cases from the source you wish to load.

Configuration

See Problem Settings to customize the unzip folder location, auto-deletion behavior, and whether to clear existing test cases before loading.

Learn more about this feature in the Feature Guide.

docs.title: Edit problem metadata
docs.text:
Click the pen-like button in the top-right corner of the problem panel to enter the edit mode.

You can modify the Title,URL,Time Limit and Memory Limit by yourself.

You can also add Special Judge (SPJ) programs or interactive libraries as required.

docs.title: Elapsed Time Tracking
docs.text: CPH-NG can now record how long has it been since the problem was being created.

docs.title: Delete a problem
docs.text:
When a problem is no longer needed, click the rightmost button in the control panel to delete it.

A confirmation dialog will appear before the problem is permanently removed.

docs.title: Load test data from embedded
docs.text: Similarly, if your file already contains embedded test data (exported previously), you can import them by using the command CPH-NG: Load from Embedded and load these with ease.

docs.title: Import from CPH-NG
docs.text:
CPH-NG is compatible with CPH.

It's feasible to import the test data from CPH to CPH-NG.

docs.title: Special Judge
docs.text:
If your program requires to judge specifically, please prepare a program for judging and add it when editing the problem.

CPH-NG supports this as well as interactive problems. Add a interactive library in a similar way if in need.

Learn More

For detailed information about Special Judge and Interactive Problems, including checker requirements and setup instructions, see the Feature Guide - Special Judge and Interactive Problems sections.

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text: This guide will help you get started with CPH-NG in minutes. For detailed information about all features, see the Feature Guide.

docs.title: Installation
docs.text:
First, the CPH-NG VS Code extension must be installed in your environment. You can install it directly by clicking this link: Install CPH-NG. Please ensure you have the latest version installed.

After installation, you'll find the extension's sidebar icon on the left side of your VS Code window. Feel free to drag it to the right side if you prefer.

First Time Setup

Before creating your first problem, you may want to configure compiler settings in Configuration.

docs.title: Create a problem
docs.text: A problem would be created after you click the CREATE button. You can do this by using the command CPH-NG: Create Problem or pressing Ctrl+Alt+B as a shortcut.

docs.title: Add test cases
docs.text:
Once the problem is created,the buttons below are able to be used.

The leftmost button is used to create a single test case. You will need to manually enter the input data and the expected answer (output).

  • Tip: CPH-NG also supports loading test cases from zipped files or specific directories, which is a great option for managing large datasets.

docs.title: Run test cases
docs.text:
• To run a single test case, click the green play button next to that test case.

  • To run all test cases simultaneously, click the middle play button in the lower control panel.

CPH-NG would show you the first judged test case which isn't accepted automatically.

If you load these test cases from files,the output would be also showed as files.Drag or click them to show them in detailed.

Now, you have already learned the basic usage of CPH-NG. Enjoy coding with CPH-NG!

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
• Explore all features in the Feature Guide
  • Learn about Configuration Options
  • Check Modules for additional functionality
  • Visit FAQ if you have questions

docs.title: Basic Settings
docs.text: General settings that control UI behavior and folder selection methods.

docs.title: cph-ng.basic.folderOpener
docs.text:
Controls which method is used for selecting folders in dialogs.

  • Type: String enum ("default" | "native")
  • Default: "default"
  • User Impact:
  • "default": Uses VS Code's standard folder picker (works in all environments including remote development)
  • "native": Uses system native folder dialog (may provide better UX on local systems but doesn't work in remote/web environments)

Example: 

{
  "cph-ng.basic.folderOpener": "native"
}

When loading test cases from a folder, the system's native folder picker will be used instead of VS Code's dialog.

docs.title: When to Change This Setting
docs.text:
• Use "default": If you work with remote development (SSH, WSL, containers), or experience issues with folder selection
  • Use "native": If you prefer your operating system's folder picker and work only on local files

docs.title: Related Features
docs.text: • Load Test Cases - Uses folder selection when loading from folders

docs.title: Brute Force Compare Settings
docs.text: Settings for the brute force comparison feature that automatically finds failing test cases.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: Brute force comparison helps you find edge cases by: 1. Running a generator to create random inputs 2. Running your solution on those inputs 3. Running a known-correct brute force solution 4. Comparing outputs to find discrepancies

docs.title: cph-ng.bfCompare.generatorTimeLimit
docs.text:
Maximum time (in milliseconds) allowed for the test case generator to run.

  • Type: Number
  • Default: 3000 (3 seconds)
  • User Impact: If the generator takes longer than this to produce a test case, it will be terminated. Increase if your generator needs more time for complex test cases.

Example: 

{
  "cph-ng.bfCompare.generatorTimeLimit": 5000
}

Allow generator up to 5 seconds to create each test case.

docs.title: cph-ng.bfCompare.bruteForceTimeLimit
docs.text:
Maximum time (in milliseconds) allowed for the brute force solution to run.

  • Type: Number
  • Default: 10000 (10 seconds)
  • User Impact: If the brute force solution takes longer than this, it will be terminated. Brute force solutions are often slow, so this is typically higher than normal time limits.

Example: 

{
  "cph-ng.bfCompare.bruteForceTimeLimit": 30000
}

Allow brute force solution up to 30 seconds per test case.

docs.title: How It Works
docs.text:
1. Generator Execution: Creates a random test input (limited by generatorTimeLimit)
  2. Your Solution: Runs on the generated input (uses problem's time limit)
  3. Brute Force Solution: Runs on the same input (limited by bruteForceTimeLimit)
  4. Comparison: Outputs are compared
  5. Result:
  6. If outputs match: Try another test case
  7. If outputs differ: Found failing case! Saved for debugging

docs.title: Disk Operations
docs.text:
When a failing test case is found:

  1. Input Saved: Generated input is saved to disk as a new test case
  2. Your Output: Your solution's output is recorded
  3. Expected Output: Brute force solution's output becomes the expected answer
  4. Problem Updated: New test case is added to the problem file
  5. Files Updated: Problem data file (.cph-ng/*.bin) is updated with the new test case

docs.title: When to Adjust These Settings
docs.text:
Increase generatorTimeLimit when: - Generator creates complex structures (graphs, trees) - Generator validates constraints - Getting timeout errors during generation

Increase bruteForceTimeLimit when: - Brute force solution has high complexity (O(n³), O(2ⁿ)) - Testing with large inputs - Getting timeout on correct brute force solutions

Decrease timeouts when: - Want faster iteration (test more cases per minute) - Generator and brute force are very fast - Working with small inputs

docs.title: For Simple Problems
docs.text:
{
  "cph-ng.bfCompare.generatorTimeLimit": 1000,
  "cph-ng.bfCompare.bruteForceTimeLimit": 5000
}

docs.title: For Complex Problems
docs.text:
{
  "cph-ng.bfCompare.generatorTimeLimit": 10000,
  "cph-ng.bfCompare.bruteForceTimeLimit": 60000
}

docs.title: Related Features
docs.text:
• Brute Force Compare - Main feature documentation
  • Add Test Case - Where found cases are saved
  • Runner Settings - Your solution uses standard runner settings

docs.title: Cache Settings
docs.text: Settings that control compilation caching to speed up repeated compilations.

docs.title: cph-ng.cache.cacheDirectory
docs.text:
Location where compilation cache files are stored.

  • Type: String (path template)
  • Default: "${tmp}/cph-ng"
  • User Impact: Determines where compiled binaries and cache data are stored on disk. Changing this affects:
  • Disk space usage location
  • Cache persistence across sessions
  • Multi-workspace cache sharing

Path Variables:

Variable Description ${tmp} System temporary directory ${workspace} Workspace root directory ${home} User home directory

Examples:

{
  "cph-ng.cache.cacheDirectory": "${workspace}/.cache/cph-ng"
}

Stores cache in workspace (persists with project, not shared between projects).

{
  "cph-ng.cache.cacheDirectory": "${home}/.cache/cph-ng"
}

Stores cache in home directory (shared between all projects, persists after closing VS Code).

docs.title: cph-ng.cache.cleanOnStartup
docs.text:
Automatically clean cache directory when VS Code starts.

  • Type: Boolean
  • Default: false
  • User Impact:
  • false: Cache persists between sessions (faster first compilation)
  • true: Cache is cleared on startup (ensures fresh compilation, uses more disk space temporarily)

Example: 

{
  "cph-ng.cache.cleanOnStartup": true
}

Cache is cleared every time you start VS Code.

docs.title: Compilation Cache
docs.text:
When you compile a program:

  1. Hash Calculation: CPH-NG calculates a hash based on:
  2. Source code content
  3. Compiler path and arguments

  4. Compilation settings

  5. Cache Check: Looks for cached binary with matching hash

  6. Cache Hit: If found, reuses compiled binary (skip compilation)

  7. Cache Miss: Compiles and stores binary in cache with hash

  8. Cache Location: Binary saved to ${cacheDirectory}/${hash}.o

docs.title: Benefits
docs.text:
• Faster Testing: No recompilation when source hasn't changed
  • Quick Retries: Rerunning same tests is instant
  • Lower CPU Usage: Less compilation overhead

docs.title: Disk Usage
docs.text:
Each unique compilation creates a cached binary file:

  • Typical Size: 100KB - 5MB per binary (depends on source code size and compilation flags)
  • Growth: Cache grows as you work on different problems and make changes
  • Cleanup: Automatically cleaned if cleanOnStartup is true, or manually delete the cache directory

docs.title: When to Change These Settings
docs.text:
Change cacheDirectory when: - Want cache to persist with project (use ${workspace}/.cache) - Want cache shared globally (use ${home}/.cache) - Using remote development (use location accessible in remote environment) - Need to control disk usage location

Enable cleanOnStartup when: - Experiencing compilation issues - Disk space is limited - Want to ensure fresh compilation every session - Debugging compilation problems

Keep cleanOnStartup false when: - Want maximum performance - Have plenty of disk space - Frequently recompile same code

docs.title: Manual Cache Cleanup
docs.text:
You can manually clean the cache by deleting the cache directory:

Linux/macOS: 

rm -rf /tmp/cph-ng

Windows: 

rd /s /q %TEMP%\cph-ng

Or use the location specified in your cacheDirectory setting.

docs.title: Related Features
docs.text:
• Compilation Settings - Compiler settings affect cache hash
  • Run Single Test - Benefits from caching
  • Run All Tests - Only compiles once due to caching

docs.title: Competitive Companion Settings
docs.text: Settings for integration with the Competitive Companion browser extension.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: Competitive Companion is a browser extension that can automatically send problem information from online judges (Codeforces, AtCoder, etc.) directly to CPH-NG.

docs.title: cph-ng.companion.listenPort
docs.text:
Port number CPH-NG listens on for Competitive Companion connections.

  • Type: Number
  • Default: 10046
  • User Impact: This must match the port configured in your Competitive Companion browser extension. If you change this, update the extension settings too.

Example: 

{
  "cph-ng.companion.listenPort": 10050
}

Change if port 10046 is already in use by another application.

Port Conflicts

If another application uses this port, Competitive Companion won't work. Change to an available port (1024-65535).

docs.title: cph-ng.companion.defaultExtension
docs.text:
Default file extension for problems imported from Competitive Companion.

  • Type: String
  • Default: ".cpp"
  • User Impact: When importing a problem, a new file with this extension is automatically created if it doesn't exist.

Options: - ".cpp" - C++ - ".c" - C - ".java" - Java

Example: 

{
  "cph-ng.companion.defaultExtension": ".java"
}

Problems imported from browser will create .java files.

docs.title: cph-ng.companion.chooseSaveFolder
docs.text:
Prompt for save location when importing problems.

  • Type: Boolean
  • Default: false
  • User Impact:
  • false: Problems saved to current workspace automatically
  • true: You're prompted to choose save location for each problem

Example: 

{
  "cph-ng.companion.chooseSaveFolder": true
}

You'll be asked where to save each imported problem.

docs.title: cph-ng.companion.addTimestamp
docs.text:
Add timestamp to filenames when importing problems.

  • Type: Number (enum: 0, 1, 2)
  • Default: 0
  • Values:
  • 0: No timestamp
  • 1: Add timestamp if file exists

  • 2: Always add timestamp

  • User Impact: Controls filename collision handling:

  • 0: A.cpp (overwrites if exists)
  • 1: A.cpp first time, A-1234567890.cpp if exists
  • 2: A-1234567890.cpp always

Example: 

{
  "cph-ng.companion.addTimestamp": 1
}

Adds timestamp only when filename conflicts occur.

docs.title: cph-ng.companion.shortCodeforcesName
docs.text:
Use shorter names for Codeforces problems.

  • Type: Boolean
  • Default: false
  • User Impact:
  • false: Uses full names like Codeforces Round 123 - Problem A - Title
  • true: Uses short names like A or 123A

Example: 

{
  "cph-ng.companion.shortCodeforcesName": true
}

Imported Codeforces problems get short names: A.cpp, B.cpp, etc.

docs.title: cph-ng.companion.shortLuoguName
docs.text:
Use shorter names for Luogu problems.

  • Type: Boolean
  • Default: false
  • User Impact: Similar to Codeforces, controls whether to use full problem titles or short identifiers.

Example: 

{
  "cph-ng.companion.shortLuoguName": true
}

docs.title: cph-ng.companion.shortAtCoderName
docs.text:
Use shorter names for AtCoder problems.

  • Type: Boolean
  • Default: false
  • User Impact: Similar to Codeforces, controls whether to use full problem titles or short identifiers.

Example: 

{
  "cph-ng.companion.shortAtCoderName": true
}

docs.title: cph-ng.companion.showPanel
docs.text:
Control visibility of problem source file when importing.

  • Type: Number (enum: 0, 1, 2)
  • Default: 2
  • Values:
  • 0: Never show source file
  • 1: Show only if file is new

  • 2: Always show source file

  • User Impact: Controls whether the imported source file opens in editor:

  • 0: File created but not opened
  • 1: Opens only newly created files
  • 2: Always opens the file

Example: 

{
  "cph-ng.companion.showPanel": 0
}

Files are created but not automatically opened in editor.

docs.title: cph-ng.companion.submitLanguage
docs.text:
Default language ID for submissions to online judges.

  • Type: Number
  • Default: 54 (C++17 GCC)
  • User Impact: When submitting to Codeforces or other judges, this language is selected by default. Language IDs vary by platform.

Common Language IDs (Codeforces): - 43: GNU G++17 7.3.0 - 54: GNU G++17 9.2.0 - 73: GNU G++20 11.2.0 - 87: GNU G++20 13.2.0

Example: 

{
  "cph-ng.companion.submitLanguage": 73
}

Use C++20 (GCC 11) for submissions.

Finding Language IDs

Check the language dropdown on the judge's submission page to find the correct ID for your preferred language and compiler version.

docs.title: Codeforces Competitive Setup
docs.text:
{
  "cph-ng.companion.shortCodeforcesName": true,
  "cph-ng.companion.addTimestamp": 0,
  "cph-ng.companion.showPanel": 2,
  "cph-ng.companion.submitLanguage": 73
}

docs.title: Multi-Judge Setup
docs.text:
{
  "cph-ng.companion.shortCodeforcesName": true,
  "cph-ng.companion.shortAtCoderName": true,
  "cph-ng.companion.shortLuoguName": true,
  "cph-ng.companion.chooseSaveFolder": true
}

docs.title: How It Works
docs.text:
When you click Competitive Companion in your browser:

  1. Extension Connects: Browser extension connects to localhost:10046 (or your configured port)
  2. Data Sent: Problem metadata and test cases sent to CPH-NG
  3. File Created: Source file created with defaultExtension in chosen/current location
  4. Naming Applied: Filename determined by platform-specific naming settings
  5. Problem Initialized: Problem structure created with received test cases
  6. Disk Operations:
  7. Source file written: ${workspace}/${problemName}.cpp
  8. Problem data written: ${workspace}/.cph-ng/${problemName}.cpp.bin
  9. UI Update: Problem panel shown based on showPanel setting

docs.title: Related Features
docs.text:
• Competitive Companion - How to use the integration
  • Import Problem - Manual import alternative
  • Submit to Codeforces - Uses submitLanguage setting

docs.title: Comparing Settings
docs.text: Settings that control how test outputs are compared against expected answers.

docs.title: cph-ng.comparing.oleSize
docs.text:
Threshold (in lines) for Output Limit Exceeded detection.

  • Type: Number
  • Default: 3
  • User Impact: If actual output has more than this many extra lines compared to expected answer, verdict becomes OLE (Output Limit Exceeded) instead of WA (Wrong Answer).

Example: 

{
  "cph-ng.comparing.oleSize": 5
}

Output with 6+ extra lines gets OLE instead of WA.

docs.title: cph-ng.comparing.regardPEAsAC
docs.text:
Treat Presentation Error (trailing/leading whitespace differences) as Accepted.

  • Type: Boolean
  • Default: false
  • User Impact:
  • false: Extra whitespace at line ends or extra blank lines causes PE verdict
  • true: Whitespace differences are ignored, verdict becomes AC

Example: 

{
  "cph-ng.comparing.regardPEAsAC": true
}

Trailing spaces and extra blank lines don't cause PE verdict.

Competitive Programming

Most online judges are lenient with whitespace. Setting this to true matches typical judge behavior.

docs.title: cph-ng.comparing.ignoreError
docs.text:
Controls whether stderr output is considered in verdict.

  • Type: Boolean
  • Default: true
  • User Impact:
  • true: Programs can write to stderr without affecting verdict (common for debug output)
  • false: Any stderr output causes different verdict or warning

Example: 

{
  "cph-ng.comparing.ignoreError": false
}

Programs writing to stderr will be flagged.

Debug Output

Keeping this true allows using cerr for debugging in C++ without affecting correctness checks.

docs.title: Comparison Behavior
docs.text:
The comparison process works as follows:

  1. Exact Match: Output matches answer exactly → AC (Accepted)
  2. Whitespace Differences: Trailing/leading spaces differ → PE (Presentation Error), or AC if regardPEAsAC is true
  3. Wrong Content: Output content differs → WA (Wrong Answer)
  4. Too Much Output: More than oleSize extra lines → OLE (Output Limit Exceeded)
  5. Runtime Error: Program crashes or returns non-zero exit code → RE (Runtime Error)
  6. Time Limit: Execution exceeds time limit → TLE (Time Limit Exceeded)
  7. Memory Limit: Memory usage exceeds limit (if runner enabled) → MLE (Memory Limit Exceeded)

docs.title: When to Change These Settings
docs.text:
Set regardPEAsAC to true: - Preparing for online judges that ignore whitespace - Don't want to worry about output formatting - Focus on algorithm correctness

Set regardPEAsAC to false: - Need exact output format matching - Testing output formatting requirements - Preparing for strict formatting contests

Set ignoreError to false: - Debugging programs that shouldn't write to stderr - Want to catch all diagnostic output - Testing code quality

Adjust oleSize: - Getting incorrect OLE verdicts - Want stricter or more lenient detection

docs.title: Related Features
docs.text:
• Compare Output - Visual diff for WA/PE cases
  • Run Single Test - Uses these comparison rules
  • Run All Tests - Applies to all test comparisons
  • Special Judge - Overrides standard comparison

docs.title: Compilation Settings
docs.text: Settings that control how CPH-NG compiles your source code for C, C++, and Java.

docs.title: cph-ng.compilation.cPath
docs.text:
Path to the C compiler executable.

  • Type: String (executable path)
  • Default: "gcc"
  • User Impact: Specifies which C compiler to use. Must be accessible in your system PATH or provide full path.

Example: 

{
  "cph-ng.compilation.cPath": "/usr/bin/clang"
}

docs.title: cph-ng.compilation.cppPath
docs.text:
Path to the C++ compiler executable.

  • Type: String (executable path)
  • Default: "g++"
  • User Impact: Specifies which C++ compiler to use. Must be accessible in your system PATH or provide full path.

Example: 

{
  "cph-ng.compilation.cppPath": "/usr/bin/clang++"
}

docs.title: cph-ng.compilation.javaPath
docs.text:
Path to the Java compiler executable.

  • Type: String (executable path)
  • Default: "javac"
  • User Impact: Specifies which Java compiler to use. Must be accessible in your system PATH or provide full path.

Example: 

{
  "cph-ng.compilation.javaPath": "/usr/lib/jvm/java-17/bin/javac"
}

docs.title: cph-ng.compilation.cArgs
docs.text:
Additional arguments passed to the C compiler.

  • Type: String
  • Default: "-O2 -std=gnu11 -Wall"
  • User Impact: Controls optimization level, language standard, and warnings. Common use cases:
  • Optimization: -O0 (debug), -O2 (standard), -O3 (aggressive)
  • Standards: -std=c11, -std=c17, -std=gnu11
  • Warnings: -Wall, -Wextra, -Werror
  • Debugging: -g
  • Sanitizers: -fsanitize=address, -fsanitize=undefined

Examples:

{
  "cph-ng.compilation.cArgs": "-O3 -std=c17 -Wall -Wextra"
}

Use C17 standard with aggressive optimization and extra warnings.

{
  "cph-ng.compilation.cArgs": "-g -O0 -std=c11 -Wall -fsanitize=address"
}

Debug configuration with address sanitizer to catch memory errors.

docs.title: cph-ng.compilation.cppArgs
docs.text:
Additional arguments passed to the C++ compiler.

  • Type: String
  • Default: "-O2 -std=gnu++17 -Wall"
  • User Impact: Controls C++ compilation. Common use cases:
  • Standards: -std=c++11, -std=c++14, -std=c++17, -std=c++20, -std=gnu++17
  • Optimizations: Same as C
  • Debugging: -g, -fsanitize=address, -fsanitize=undefined
  • Platform: -m32 (32-bit), -m64 (64-bit)

Examples:

{
  "cph-ng.compilation.cppArgs": "-O2 -std=c++20 -Wall"
}

Use C++20 standard with O2 optimization for competitive programming.

{
  "cph-ng.compilation.cppArgs": "-g -O0 -std=c++17 -Wall -fsanitize=address,undefined"
}

Debug with multiple sanitizers to catch memory and undefined behavior errors.

docs.title: cph-ng.compilation.javaArgs
docs.text:
Additional arguments passed to the Java compiler.

  • Type: String
  • Default: "-encoding UTF-8"
  • User Impact: Controls Java compilation options.

Example: 

{
  "cph-ng.compilation.javaArgs": "-encoding UTF-8 -Xlint:all"
}

Enable all compiler warnings.

docs.title: cph-ng.compilation.timeout
docs.text:
Maximum time allowed for compilation (in milliseconds).

  • Type: Number
  • Default: 3000 (3 seconds)
  • User Impact: If compilation takes longer than this, it will be terminated. Increase if you have large projects or slower systems.

Example: 

{
  "cph-ng.compilation.timeout": 10000
}

Allow up to 10 seconds for compilation.

docs.title: cph-ng.compilation.wrapper
docs.text:
Command wrapper that executes before the compiler.

  • Type: String
  • Default: "" (empty)
  • User Impact: Runs before compilation. Use cases:
  • Environment setup
  • Custom build scripts
  • Compiler selection based on conditions

Example: 

{
  "cph-ng.compilation.wrapper": "ccache"
}

Use ccache to speed up recompilation.

docs.title: cph-ng.compilation.beforeCompileHook
docs.text:
Command executed before compilation starts.

  • Type: String
  • Default: "" (empty)
  • User Impact: Runs as a separate command before compilation. Use cases:
  • Pre-processing source files
  • Generating code
  • Checking dependencies

docs.title: cph-ng.compilation.afterCompileHook
docs.text:
Command executed after compilation completes.

  • Type: String
  • Default: "" (empty)
  • User Impact: Runs after successful compilation. Use cases:
  • Post-processing binaries
  • Running static analyzers
  • Copying output files

docs.title: Related Features
docs.text:
• Run Single Test - Compiles before running
  • Run All Tests - Compiles once for all tests
  • Cache Settings - Affects compilation speed through caching

docs.title: CPH Compatibility Settings
docs.text: Settings that control integration with the original CPH (Competitive Programming Helper) extension.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: CPH-NG can import problems created with the original CPH extension, allowing you to migrate existing problems or use both extensions in parallel.

docs.title: cph-ng.cphCapable.checkOnStartup
docs.text:
Automatically check for CPH problems when opening files.

  • Type: Boolean
  • Default: true
  • User Impact:
  • true: CPH-NG detects when you open a file with existing CPH data and offers to import it
  • false: No automatic detection; manual import only

Example: 

{
  "cph-ng.cphCapable.checkOnStartup": false
}

Disable automatic CPH problem detection.

docs.title: cph-ng.cphCapable.checkInterval
docs.text:
How often to check for CPH problems (in milliseconds).

  • Type: Number
  • Default: 5000 (5 seconds)
  • User Impact: Controls the delay between checks when opening files. Lower values mean faster detection but slightly more resource usage.

Example: 

{
  "cph-ng.cphCapable.checkInterval": 10000
}

Check for CPH problems every 10 seconds.

docs.title: Detection Process
docs.text:
1. File Open: When you open a source file (.cpp, .c, .java)
  2. CPH Check: CPH-NG looks for .cph/ folder in the workspace
  3. Problem Match: Searches for matching problem file (.cph/.{filename}.prob)
  4. Import Prompt: If found and not already imported, shows import button

docs.title: Import Process
docs.text:
When you click the import button:

  1. Read CPH Data: Reads problem metadata from .cph/.{filename}.prob
  2. Convert Format: Transforms CPH format to CPH-NG format
  3. Create Problem: Creates CPH-NG problem structure
  4. Save Data: Writes to .cph-ng/{filename}.bin
  5. Preserve Original: Original CPH .prob file remains unchanged

docs.title: File Structure
docs.text:
Original CPH: 

workspace/
├── problem.cpp
└── .cph/
    └── .problem.cpp.prob  (CPH format - JSON)

After CPH-NG Import: 

workspace/
├── problem.cpp
├── .cph/
│   └── .problem.cpp.prob  (Original CPH - preserved)
└── .cph-ng/
    └── problem.cpp.bin    (CPH-NG format - compressed)

docs.title: Data Migration
docs.text:
CPH-NG imports the following from CPH:

  • ✅ Problem name
  • ✅ Test cases (input and expected output)
  • ✅ Time limit
  • ✅ Memory limit
  • ✅ Source file path
  • ❌ Custom checkers (not supported in CPH)
  • ❌ Interactive problems (not supported in CPH)

docs.title: When to Change These Settings
docs.text:
Disable checkOnStartup when: - Not using original CPH extension - Don't want automatic detection - Performance concerns - Want to manually control imports

Increase checkInterval when: - Experiencing performance issues - Don't need immediate detection - Working with many files

Keep Default Settings when: - Migrating from CPH to CPH-NG - Using both extensions simultaneously - Want seamless import experience

docs.title: One-Time Migration
docs.text:
If migrating all problems from CPH to CPH-NG:

  1. Keep checkOnStartup: true
  2. Open each file with CPH problems
  3. Click import button when prompted
  4. After all imported, set checkOnStartup: false to disable checks

docs.title: Parallel Usage
docs.text:
If using both CPH and CPH-NG:

  1. Keep checkOnStartup: true
  2. CPH-NG will detect and import new CPH problems automatically
  3. Both extensions can work on different problems
  4. Each has its own data folder (.cph vs .cph-ng)

docs.title: Import Button Not Showing
docs.text:
Possible causes: - checkOnStartup is false → Enable it - No .cph/ folder in workspace → Verify CPH problems exist - Problem already imported → Check .cph-ng/ folder - File not active → Make sure file is open in editor

Solution: - Enable checkOnStartup - Use "CPH-NG: Import from CPH" command manually

docs.title: Import Fails
docs.text:
Possible causes: - Corrupted .prob file - Incompatible CPH version - File permission issues

Solution: - Check .prob file is valid JSON - Manually create problem in CPH-NG - Check file permissions

docs.title: Manual Import
docs.text:
You can always manually import using command palette:

  1. Press Ctrl+Shift+P (Windows/Linux) or Cmd+Shift+P (macOS)
  2. Type and select: CPH-NG: Import from CPH
  3. Select problems to import

This works regardless of checkOnStartup setting.

docs.title: Related Features
docs.text:
• CPH Import - Detailed import process
  • Create Problem - Alternative to importing
  • Import Problem - Import from CPH-NG format

docs.title: Configuration Reference
docs.text: Complete reference for all CPH-NG configuration settings, organized by category.

docs.title: Setting Categories
docs.text: CPH-NG provides 10 categories of settings to customize behavior:

docs.title: 1. Basic Settings
docs.text:
General extension behavior and UI preferences.

Key Settings: - Folder selection method

Related Features: Load Test Cases

docs.title: 2. Compilation Settings
docs.text:
Compiler configuration for C, C++, and Java.

Key Settings: - Compiler paths and arguments - Compilation timeout - Wrapper and hook support

Related Features: Run Single Test, Run All Tests

docs.title: 3. Runner Settings
docs.text:
Program execution and resource measurement.

Key Settings: - Time additions and thresholds - Output size limits - Advanced runner for memory tracking

Related Features: Run Single Test, Run All Tests

docs.title: 4. Comparing Settings
docs.text:
Output comparison and verdict determination.

Key Settings: - Output limit exceeded threshold - Presentation error handling - Error output behavior

Related Features: Compare Output, Run Single Test

docs.title: 5. Brute Force Compare Settings
docs.text:
Settings for brute force comparison feature.

Key Settings: - Generator time limit - Brute force solution timeout

Related Features: Brute Force Compare

docs.title: 6. Problem Settings
docs.text:
Problem file management and defaults.

Key Settings: - Default time and memory limits - File path templates - Template file location - Test case loading behavior

Related Features: Create Problem, Edit Problem, Load Test Cases

docs.title: 7. Cache Settings
docs.text:
Compilation cache and temporary files.

Key Settings: - Cache directory location - Cleanup behavior

Related Features: Run Single Test, Run All Tests

docs.title: 8. CPH Compatibility Settings
docs.text:
Integration with original CPH extension.

Key Settings: - Automatic CPH detection - Import compatibility options

Related Features: CPH Import, Import Problem

docs.title: 9. Competitive Companion Settings
docs.text:
Browser extension integration settings.

Key Settings: - Listen port configuration - File naming conventions - Auto-import behavior - Platform-specific options - Submission settings

Related Features: Competitive Companion, Submit to Codeforces

docs.title: 10. Sidebar Settings
docs.text:
UI customization for the CPH-NG panel.

Key Settings: - Theme and colors - Status display options - Font customization - Animation preferences

Related Features: All features (affects UI display)

docs.title: Path Variables
docs.text:
Many settings support template variables for flexible path configuration:

Variable Description Example ${workspace} Workspace root /home/user/project ${tmp} System temp directory /tmp ${home} User home directory /home/user ${dirname} File directory /home/user/project/src ${relativeDirname} Relative directory src ${basename} Filename with extension main.cpp ${basenameNoExt} Filename without extension main ${extname} File extension .cpp

docs.title: Settings Access
docs.text:
VS Code UI: 1. Press Ctrl+, (Windows/Linux) or Cmd+, (macOS) 2. Search for "cph-ng" 3. Browse and modify settings

settings.json: 

{
  "cph-ng.problem.defaultTimeLimit": 2000,
  "cph-ng.compilation.cppArgs": "-O2 -std=c++20 -Wall"
}

docs.title: Competitive Programming Setup
docs.text:
{
  "cph-ng.problem.defaultTimeLimit": 2000,
  "cph-ng.problem.defaultMemoryLimit": 256,
  "cph-ng.compilation.cppArgs": "-O2 -std=c++17 -Wall",
  "cph-ng.companion.shortCodeforcesName": true,
  "cph-ng.comparing.regardPEAsAC": false
}

docs.title: Debug Configuration
docs.text:
{
  "cph-ng.compilation.cppArgs": "-g -O0 -std=c++20 -Wall -fsanitize=address",
  "cph-ng.runner.useRunner": true,
  "cph-ng.comparing.ignoreError": false
}

docs.title: Performance Optimization
docs.text:
{
  "cph-ng.cache.cleanOnStartup": false,
  "cph-ng.compilation.timeout": 5000,
  "cph-ng.runner.timeAddition": 500
}

docs.title: Navigation
docs.text:
Click any category above to view detailed settings documentation with:

  • Setting descriptions and types
  • Default values
  • User impact explanations
  • Configuration examples
  • Related features

docs.title: Need Help?
docs.text:
• Check FAQ for common questions
  • See Quick Start for basic setup
  • Visit individual feature pages for feature-specific settings

docs.title: Problem Settings
docs.text: Settings that control problem file management, default limits, and test case handling.

docs.title: cph-ng.problem.defaultTimeLimit
docs.text:
Sets the default time limit for newly created problems.

  • Type: Number (milliseconds)
  • Default: 1000
  • User Impact: When you create a new problem, this value is automatically used as the time limit. Tests exceeding this limit will receive Time Limit Exceeded (TLE) verdict.

Example: 

{
  "cph-ng.problem.defaultTimeLimit": 2000
}

New problems will have 2000ms (2 seconds) time limit.

docs.title: cph-ng.problem.defaultMemoryLimit
docs.text:
Sets the default memory limit for newly created problems.

  • Type: Number (megabytes)
  • Default: 512
  • User Impact: When you create a new problem, this value is automatically used as the memory limit. Programs exceeding this limit may receive Memory Limit Exceeded (MLE) verdict (if runner is enabled).

Example: 

{
  "cph-ng.problem.defaultMemoryLimit": 256
}

New problems will have 256MB memory limit.

docs.title: cph-ng.problem.problemFilePath
docs.text:
Template pattern that determines where problem data files are stored on disk.

  • Type: String (path template)
  • Default: "${workspace}/.cph-ng/${relativeDirname}/${basename}.bin"
  • User Impact: Controls the folder structure where your problem data is saved. Changing this affects where you'll find your problem files in the file explorer.

Path Variables:

Variable Description Example ${workspace} Your workspace root /home/user/project ${dirname} Full directory path /home/user/project/src ${relativeDirname} Directory relative to workspace src ${basename} Filename with extension main.cpp ${basenameNoExt} Filename without extension main ${extname} File extension .cpp

Examples:

{
  "cph-ng.problem.problemFilePath": "${workspace}/.cph/${basenameNoExt}.bin"
}

Stores all problems in a single .cph folder: .cph/main.bin, .cph/problem2.bin, etc.

{
  "cph-ng.problem.problemFilePath": "${dirname}/.cph-ng/${basename}.bin"
}

Stores problems in .cph-ng folder next to source file.

docs.title: cph-ng.problem.binaryFilePath
docs.text:
Template pattern for compiled binary output location.

  • Type: String (path template)
  • Default: "${workspace}/.cph-ng/${relativeDirname}/${basenameNoExt}${extname}.o"
  • User Impact: Determines where compiled executables are stored. This affects disk space usage and cleanup.

docs.title: cph-ng.problem.templateFile
docs.text:
Path to a template file used when creating new problem source files.

  • Type: String (file path)
  • Default: "" (empty - no template)
  • User Impact: If set, new problem source files will be initialized with content from this template file. Useful for including standard libraries, macros, or boilerplate code.

Example: 

{
  "cph-ng.problem.templateFile": "${workspace}/template.cpp"
}

When creating a new problem, the source file will be initialized with content from template.cpp.

docs.title: cph-ng.problem.clearBeforeLoadTestCases
docs.text:
Controls whether existing test cases are cleared when loading new ones from files.

  • Type: Boolean
  • Default: false
  • User Impact:
  • false: New test cases are added to existing ones
  • true: All existing test cases are deleted before loading new ones

Example: 

{
  "cph-ng.problem.clearBeforeLoadTestCases": true
}

Loading test cases from a folder will replace all existing test cases instead of appending.

docs.title: cph-ng.problem.deleteAfterUnzip
docs.text:
Controls whether zip files are automatically deleted after extracting test cases.

  • Type: Boolean
  • Default: false
  • User Impact:
  • true: Zip file is deleted after extraction (saves disk space)
  • false: Zip file is kept (allows reloading from same file)

Example: 

{
  "cph-ng.problem.deleteAfterUnzip": true
}

When loading test cases from a zip file, the zip is automatically deleted after extraction.

docs.title: Related Features
docs.text:
• Create Problem - Uses default limits
  • Edit Problem - Modify limits after creation
  • Load Test Cases - Uses test case loading settings

docs.title: Runner Settings
docs.text: Settings that control program execution, resource measurement, and output handling.

docs.title: cph-ng.runner.useRunner
docs.text:
Enable advanced runner for accurate memory and resource measurement.

  • Type: Boolean
  • Default: false
  • User Impact:
  • false: Uses standard process execution (faster, but no memory measurement)
  • true: Uses advanced runner that can measure memory usage and provide more accurate resource tracking

Example: 

{
  "cph-ng.runner.useRunner": true
}

Enables memory measurement and more accurate resource tracking.

Performance Note

Enabling the runner adds slight overhead but provides accurate memory measurement, which is useful for memory-limited problems.

docs.title: cph-ng.runner.timeAddition
docs.text:
Additional time (in milliseconds) added to the time limit when running tests.

  • Type: Number
  • Default: 200
  • User Impact: Adds buffer time to account for process startup and system overhead. The program can run slightly longer than the problem's time limit without getting TLE.

Example: 

{
  "cph-ng.runner.timeAddition": 500
}

Allows 500ms extra time for startup overhead.

docs.title: cph-ng.runner.stderrThreshold
docs.text:
Maximum standard error output size (in bytes) before showing warning.

  • Type: Number
  • Default: 100000 (100KB)
  • User Impact: If your program writes more than this to stderr, a warning is shown. Helps catch programs with excessive debug output.

Example: 

{
  "cph-ng.runner.stderrThreshold": 1000000
}

Allow up to 1MB of stderr before warning.

docs.title: cph-ng.runner.stdoutThreshold
docs.text:
Maximum standard output size (in bytes) before truncation.

  • Type: Number
  • Default: 100000 (100KB)
  • User Impact: Output larger than this is truncated. Prevents memory issues from programs that print excessive output.

Example: 

{
  "cph-ng.runner.stdoutThreshold": 500000
}

Allow up to 500KB of output.

docs.title: When to Change These Settings
docs.text:
Enable Runner When: - You need accurate memory measurement - Working on memory-limited problems - Debugging memory leaks

Increase Time Addition When: - Running on slower systems - Getting false TLE on startup - Using sanitizers that add overhead

Adjust Thresholds When: - Working with problems that produce large output - Debugging programs with verbose logging - Getting truncation warnings

docs.title: Related Features
docs.text:
• Run Single Test - Uses these settings during execution
  • Run All Tests - Applies settings to all test runs
  • Edit Problem - Set time/memory limits per problem

docs.title: Sidebar Settings
docs.text: Settings that customize the appearance of the CPH-NG problem panel sidebar.

docs.title: cph-ng.sidebar.theme
docs.text:
Color theme for the sidebar panel.

  • Type: String enum
  • Default: "default"
  • Options: "default", "light", "dark"
  • User Impact: Controls the color scheme of the problem panel:
  • "default": Follows VS Code theme
  • "light": Always use light theme
  • "dark": Always use dark theme

Example: 

{
  "cph-ng.sidebar.theme": "dark"
}

Problem panel uses dark theme regardless of VS Code theme.

docs.title: cph-ng.sidebar.fontFamily
docs.text:
Font family for text in the sidebar panel.

  • Type: String
  • Default: "" (empty - uses system default)
  • User Impact: Changes the font used for test cases, output, and problem information. Use font names installed on your system.

Examples:

{
  "cph-ng.sidebar.fontFamily": "JetBrains Mono"
}

Use JetBrains Mono font for all panel text.

{
  "cph-ng.sidebar.fontFamily": "Fira Code, Consolas, monospace"
}

Use Fira Code with fallbacks.

Monospace Fonts

For better alignment of input/output data, use monospace fonts like: - JetBrains Mono - Fira Code - Source Code Pro - Consolas (Windows default) - Monaco (macOS default)

docs.title: cph-ng.sidebar.showElapsedTime
docs.text:
Display elapsed time since problem was created.

  • Type: Boolean
  • Default: true
  • User Impact:
  • true: Shows time tracker in problem panel (e.g., "15m 30s elapsed")
  • false: Hides elapsed time display

Example: 

{
  "cph-ng.sidebar.showElapsedTime": false
}

Hide the problem elapsed time display.

docs.title: cph-ng.sidebar.showMemory
docs.text:
Display memory usage for test case results.

  • Type: Boolean
  • Default: true (when runner enabled)
  • User Impact:
  • true: Shows memory usage in test results (requires runner to be enabled)
  • false: Hides memory information

Example: 

{
  "cph-ng.sidebar.showMemory": false
}

Don't show memory usage even if measured.

Memory Measurement

Memory is only measured when cph-ng.runner.useRunner is true. This setting only controls visibility.

docs.title: cph-ng.sidebar.enableAnimations
docs.text:
Enable animations in the sidebar panel.

  • Type: Boolean
  • Default: true
  • User Impact:
  • true: Smooth transitions when expanding/collapsing test cases
  • false: Instant transitions (better for slower systems)

Example: 

{
  "cph-ng.sidebar.enableAnimations": false
}

Disable animations for instant UI updates.

docs.title: When to Customize
docs.text:
Change Theme: - Want consistent appearance regardless of VS Code theme - Better contrast for test results - Personal preference

Set Font Family: - Prefer specific monospace font - Better readability for test data - Consistent with editor font

Disable Elapsed Time: - Don't track time spent on problems - Want cleaner interface - Time tracking is distracting

Hide Memory: - Memory not relevant to your problems - Want simpler test results - Not using runner

Disable Animations: - Performance issues on slower systems - Prefer instant feedback - Animations are distracting

docs.title: Minimal Interface
docs.text:
{
  "cph-ng.sidebar.showElapsedTime": false,
  "cph-ng.sidebar.showMemory": false,
  "cph-ng.sidebar.enableAnimations": false
}

docs.title: Custom Font Setup
docs.text:
{
  "cph-ng.sidebar.fontFamily": "JetBrains Mono, Consolas, monospace",
  "cph-ng.sidebar.theme": "dark"
}

docs.title: Performance Optimized
docs.text:
{
  "cph-ng.sidebar.enableAnimations": false,
  "cph-ng.sidebar.showMemory": false
}

docs.title: Related Features
docs.text:
• Edit Problem - Where elapsed time is shown
  • Run Single Test - Results displayed in sidebar
  • Run All Tests - Multiple results in sidebar
  • Runner Settings - Controls memory measurement

docs.title: Add Test Case
docs.text: Manually add a single test case to the current problem.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: The Add Test Case feature creates a new empty test case that can be filled with input data and expected answer. This is useful for creating custom test cases manually.

docs.title: Triggering the Feature
docs.text: Method: Sidebar Button - Click the plus icon (+) button in the problem actions panel - Located as the leftmost button below the problem title

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• A problem must be loaded for the current file
  • The source file must be active in the editor

docs.title: UI Components
docs.text: Button properties: - Icon: Plus (+) icon - Label: Localized "Add Test Case" text - Size: Large button - Position: First button in action panel (leftmost)

docs.title: How It Works
docs.text:
The extension performs these steps when adding a test case:

  1. Retrieve Problem: Gets the current active problem
  2. Create Test Case: Initializes a new empty test case object
  3. Add to Problem: Appends the test case to the problem's test cases array
  4. Update UI: Refreshes the interface to show the new test case

docs.title: Test Case Structure
docs.text: New test case is initialized with: - stdin.useFile: false (inline data mode) - stdin.data: '' (empty string) - answer.useFile: false (inline data mode) - answer.data: '' (empty string) - isExpand: false (collapsed view)

docs.title: Message Flow
docs.text: When the add test case button is clicked: 1. The webview sends an addTc message to the extension 2. The extension handler receives the message 3. The problem manager adds the new test case 4. The UI is updated to reflect the changes

docs.title: Configuration Options
docs.text:
This feature has no specific configuration settings. Test case data is stored according to:

  • Data Storage: Control file vs inline storage modes → See Toggle File/Inline feature

  • Problem Data: Where problem files are stored → See Problem Settings

docs.title: Basic Usage
docs.text:
1. Open problem panel with existing problem
  2. Click the + icon in actions panel
  3. New test case appears collapsed at bottom of test cases list
  4. Click to expand test case
  5. Enter input data in "Input" field
  6. Enter expected answer in "Answer" field
  7. Data auto-saves on blur/change

docs.title: Multiple Test Cases
docs.text:
• No limit on number of test cases
  • Each gets sequential index (#1, #2, #3, etc.)
  • Can be reordered manually in the UI
  • Can be deleted individually

docs.title: Related Features
docs.text:
• Edit Test Case - Modify test case after creation
  • Load Test Cases - Bulk import from files
  • Delete Test Case - Remove test case
  • Run Single Test Case - Execute the test

docs.title: Brute Force Compare
docs.text: Find edge cases automatically using generator, brute force, and optimized solution comparison.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: The Brute Force Compare feature helps discover edge cases and bugs by automatically generating test inputs, running both your optimized solution and a brute force reference solution, and comparing their outputs. When outputs differ, that test case is saved for debugging.

docs.title: Triggering the Feature
docs.text: Method: Brute Force Button - Click the brute force/compare arrows icon in the problem actions panel - Dialog opens for configuration - Start comparison process

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• Problem must be loaded
  • Three programs needed:
  • Generator: Creates random test inputs
  • Brute Force: Slow but correct solution
  • Your Solution: Fast solution to validate

docs.title: UI Components
docs.text: Brute Force Dialog: - Generator program selection - Brute force solution selection - Configuration options (iterations, limits) - Start/Stop buttons - Progress display - Results summary

docs.title: How It Works
docs.text:
1. Setup:
  2. User selects generator program
  3. User selects brute force solution

  4. Configures iteration limit

  5. Comparison Loop:

  6. Generator creates random input
  7. Both solutions run with same input
  8. Outputs are compared
  9. If different, mismatch found

  10. Loop continues until mismatch or limit reached

  11. Result Handling:

  12. If mismatch found:
    • Input saved as new test case
    • Both outputs saved
    • User notified

  13. If all match:

    • "No differences found" message

  14. Test Case Creation:

  15. Failing input added to test cases
  16. Expected answer from brute force
  17. Can be debugged like normal test

docs.title: Generator Requirements
docs.text: Generator program should: - Output valid test input to stdout - Generate random/varied inputs - Run quickly (under time limit) - Not require input itself

docs.title: Brute Force Requirements
docs.text: Brute force solution should: - Read input from stdin - Output correct answer to stdout - Be verified correct (even if slow) - Handle same input format as main solution

docs.title: Configuration Options
docs.text:
This feature requires specific settings:

  • Time Limits: Control how long generator and brute force can run → See Brute Force Settings

  • Compilation: Affects compilation of all three programs → See Compilation Settings

  • Runner: Your main solution uses standard runner settings → See Runner Settings

docs.title: Finding Edge Case
docs.text:
1. Write optimized solution (may have bug)
  2. Write simple brute force solution (slow but correct)
  3. Write generator (creates random inputs)
  4. Open brute force dialog
  5. Select generator program
  6. Select brute force program
  7. Set iteration limit (e.g., 1000)
  8. Click "Start"
  9. System runs comparison
  10. After 347 iterations, finds mismatch
  11. Test case auto-created with failing input
  12. Debug using that test case

docs.title: Typical Generator Example (Python)
docs.text:
import random
n = random.randint(1, 100)
print(n)
for i in range(n):
    print(random.randint(1, 1000))

docs.title: Typical Brute Force (Python)
docs.text:
n = int(input())
arr = list(map(int, input().split()))
# Simple O(n²) solution
result = 0
for i in range(n):
    for j in range(i+1, n):
        if arr[i] > arr[j]:
            result += 1
print(result)

docs.title: When No Mismatch Found
docs.text:
1. Run 10000 iterations
  2. All outputs match
  3. High confidence solution is correct
  4. Or generator not covering edge cases well

docs.title: Related Features
docs.text:
• Run Single Test - Test the found edge case
  • Add Test Case - Manually add cases if needed
  • Special Judge - Alternative validation method

docs.title: Clear Results
docs.text: Reset test case execution results.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: The Clear Results feature removes execution results from test cases, returning them to an initial state. This is useful for cleaning up the UI or preparing for a fresh test run.

docs.title: Triggering the Feature
docs.text:
Method 1: Clear All Results - Right-click in the problem actions area - Select "Clear All Results" or similar option - All test case results are cleared

Method 2: Clear Single Result - Right-click on a specific test case - Select "Clear Result" or "Clear Status" - Only that test case's result is cleared

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• Problem must be loaded
  • Test cases must exist (with or without results)

docs.title: UI Components
docs.text: Clear Options: - Available via right-click context menus - May also be available via menu button - Applies to all tests or individual tests

docs.title: How It Works
docs.text:
Clear All: 1. User triggers clear all action 2. Each test case's result data is removed 3. Verdict reset to empty 4. Execution time/memory removed 5. Output data cleared (input/answer preserved) 6. UI refreshes to show clean state

Clear Single: 1. User triggers clear for specific test 2. Only that test's result data removed 3. Other tests unaffected 4. UI updates that test only

docs.title: What Gets Cleared
docs.text:
Removed: - Verdict (AC, WA, TLE, etc.) - Execution time - Memory usage - Actual output - Error messages - Comparison data

Preserved: - Test input - Expected answer - Test case itself - Source code

docs.title: Clean Slate
docs.text: After many test runs, results accumulate: - Clear all to start fresh - Makes UI less cluttered - Easier to see new results

docs.title: Before Important Run
docs.text: Before submission or final validation: 1. Clear all results 2. Run all tests fresh 3. Verify clean pass

docs.title: After Code Changes
docs.text: After significant changes: - Old results may be confusing - Clear them to avoid confusion - Run tests with new code

docs.title: Cleaning Up
docs.text:
1. Have been running tests repeatedly
  2. Some old WA results showing
  3. Code now fixed
  4. Right-click, select "Clear All Results"
  5. All verdicts cleared
  6. Run all tests fresh
  7. See only new results

docs.title: Selective Clearing
docs.text:
1. Test cases #1-5 show old results
  2. Test cases #6-10 show new results
  3. Want to clear only old ones
  4. Right-click test #1, clear result
  5. Repeat for #2-5
  6. Tests #6-10 keep their results

docs.title: Related Features
docs.text:
• Run Single Test - Generate new results
  • Run All Tests - Generate results for all
  • Stop Execution - May leave partial results

docs.title: Compare Output
docs.text: View diff between actual output and expected answer for failed test cases.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: The Compare Output feature provides a visual diff viewer when a test case fails with Wrong Answer (WA). It highlights differences between your program's actual output and the expected answer, making it easy to identify discrepancies.

docs.title: Triggering the Feature
docs.text: Method: Compare Button - Run a test case that results in WA (Wrong Answer) - A compare/diff icon button appears in the test case output area - Click the button to open the comparison view

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• Test case must have been run
  • Test case result must be WA (Wrong Answer)
  • Both actual output and expected answer must exist

docs.title: UI Components
docs.text:
Compare Button: - Icon: Compare arrows or diff icon - Position: In test case output area (leftmost button) - Only visible for WA verdicts

Comparison View: - Split view showing expected vs actual - Differences highlighted in red and green - Line-by-line comparison - Side-by-side or unified diff format

docs.title: How It Works
docs.text:
1. Test Fails: Program produces output that doesn't match expected answer
  2. WA Verdict: Comparator determines Wrong Answer
  3. Enable Compare: Compare button becomes visible
  4. User Clicks: Opens comparison modal/panel
  5. Diff Calculation: System calculates differences between outputs
  6. Display: Shows highlighted differences

docs.title: Comparison Algorithm
docs.text: The feature performs: - Line-by-line comparison - Whitespace handling based on settings - Character-level diff for changed lines - Visual highlighting of additions/deletions

docs.title: cph-ng.comparing.regardPEAsAC
docs.text:
• Type: boolean
  • Default: false
  • Description: Treat Presentation Error as Accepted
  • Effect: If true, PE cases won't show as WA requiring comparison

docs.title: cph-ng.comparing.oleSize
docs.text:
• Type: number
  • Default: 3
  • Description: Maximum output lines difference for OLE (Output Limit Exceeded)
  • Effect: Large output differences may show OLE instead of WA

docs.title: cph-ng.comparing.ignoreError
docs.text:
• Type: boolean
  • Default: false
  • Description: Ignore stderr when comparing
  • Effect: Comparison focuses only on stdout

docs.title: Visual Indicators
docs.text:
• Red (Deleted): Lines in expected answer but not in actual output
  • Green (Added): Lines in actual output but not in expected answer
  • Highlighted Characters: Specific character differences within lines

docs.title: Set as Answer
docs.text: If you determine the expected answer was wrong: - Can click "Set as Answer" button - Updates expected answer to match actual output - Useful for correcting test case answers

docs.title: Debugging Wrong Answer
docs.text:
1. Run test case
  2. Result shows "WA"
  3. Click compare button (diff icon)
  4. Comparison view opens showing: 
    Expected:  42
Actual:    43
           ^^
  5. Identify the difference
  6. Return to code to fix the issue

docs.title: Fixing Expected Answer
docs.text:
1. Test case shows WA
  2. Open comparison
  3. Realize expected answer is incorrect
  4. Click "Set as Answer" button
  5. Expected answer updated to actual output
  6. Re-run shows AC (Accepted)

docs.title: Handling PE (Presentation Error)
docs.text: If regardPEAsAC is enabled and only whitespace differs: 1. Test case shows AC instead of WA 2. No comparison needed 3. Extra spaces/newlines ignored

docs.title: Related Features
docs.text:
• Run Single Test - Generate output to compare
  • Run All Tests - Multiple comparisons
  • Edit Test Case - Fix expected answers
  • Toggle File/Inline - For large outputs

docs.title: Competitive Companion Integration
docs.text: Browser extension integration for automatic problem import from online judges.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: Competitive Companion is a browser extension that sends problem data from online judges directly to CPH-NG. Click the extension icon on any problem page to automatically import all test cases and metadata.

docs.title: Setup
docs.text:
1. Install Competitive Companion browser extension
