  2. Configure listening port in CPH-NG settings (default: 27121)
  3. Open a source file in VS Code
  4. Navigate to problem on online judge
  5. Click Competitive Companion icon
  6. Problem auto-created in CPH-NG

docs.title: Supported Judges
docs.text:
• Codeforces
  • AtCoder
  • LeetCode
  • Codechef
  • CSES
  • And many more

docs.title: cph-ng.companion.listenPort
docs.text:
• Default: 27121
  • Browser extension sends to this port

docs.title: cph-ng.companion.shortCodeforcesName
docs.text:
• Default: true
  • Uses short problem names (A, B, C) instead of full titles

docs.title: cph-ng.companion.shortLuoguName
docs.text: • Shortens Luogu problem names

docs.title: cph-ng.companion.shortAtCoderName
docs.text: • Shortens AtCoder problem names

docs.title: cph-ng.companion.defaultExtension
docs.text:
• Default: .cpp
  • Extension for auto-created files

docs.title: cph-ng.companion.chooseSaveFolder
docs.text: • Whether to prompt for save location

docs.title: How It Works
docs.text:
1. User clicks extension icon on problem page
  2. Extension sends JSON data to CPH-NG
  3. CPH-NG receives problem metadata and test cases
  4. New file created (or existing opened)
  5. Problem imported with all test cases
  6. Ready to start coding

docs.title: Related Features
docs.text:
• Create Problem - Manual problem creation
  • Import Problem - Import from CPH

docs.title: CPH Import
docs.text: Batch import problems from original CPH extension format.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: CPH Import command allows batch importing multiple problems from the original CPH extension. Useful when migrating from CPH to CPH-NG.

docs.title: Triggering
docs.text: Command Palette: 1. Press Ctrl+Shift+P (Cmd+Shift+P on macOS) 2. Type: "CPH-NG: Import from CPH" 3. Select command 4. Choose files to import

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• CPH problem files (.prob) must exist
  • Corresponding source files should exist

docs.title: How It Works
docs.text:
1. Command invoked
  2. Scans workspace for CPH problem files
  3. Shows list of available problems
  4. User selects which to import
  5. Each selected problem is converted
  6. Imported problems saved in CPH-NG format

docs.title: Batch Import
docs.text: Unlike single Import Problem, this command: - Imports multiple problems at once - Scans entire workspace - Shows selection dialog - Preserves all problem data

docs.title: Related Features
docs.text:
• Import Problem - Single problem import
  • Create Problem - Create from scratch

docs.title: Create Problem
docs.text: Create a new competitive programming problem in your workspace.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: The Create Problem feature initializes a new problem for the currently active source file. It creates the problem metadata structure and sets up default configuration based on your settings.

docs.title: Triggering the Feature
docs.text:
Method 1: Sidebar Button - Open a source file (.cpp, .c, or .java) - Click the CREATE button in the CPH-NG sidebar panel

Method 2: Command Palette - Press Ctrl+Shift+P (Windows/Linux) or Cmd+Shift+P (macOS) - Type and select: CPH-NG: Create Problem

Method 3: Keyboard Shortcut - Press Ctrl+Alt+B (Windows/Linux) or Cmd+Alt+B (macOS)

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• An editor with a source file must be active
  • The file must have a supported extension (.cpp, .c, .java)
  • No problem should already exist for this file

docs.title: UI Components
docs.text: The create problem view displays: - Warning alert explaining the action - CREATE button with send icon - Optional IMPORT button if CPH data is detected

docs.title: How It Works
docs.text:
1. Validation
  2. Checks if a source file path exists
  3. Verifies no problem already exists for this file

  4. Shows warning message if validation fails

  5. Problem Creation

  6. Creates a new problem object
  7. Initializes with:
  8. version: Current CPH-NG version
  9. name: Filename without extension
  10. src.path: Full path to source file
  11. tcs: Empty array (no test cases initially)
  12. timeLimit: From cph-ng.problem.defaultTimeLimit
  13. memoryLimit: From cph-ng.problem.defaultMemoryLimit

  14. timeElapsed: 0 (tracking time spent on problem)

  15. Storage

  16. Calculates binary file path using template pattern
  17. Serializes problem data to JSON format
  18. Compresses data with gzip

  19. Writes to .cph-ng/ folder in workspace

  20. UI Update

  21. Loads the new problem into active problems list
  22. Updates sidebar with problem information
  23. Refreshes the webview panel

docs.title: File System
docs.text:
Problem Storage: - Default location: ${workspace}/.cph-ng/${relativeDirname}/${basename}.bin - Configurable via cph-ng.problem.problemFilePath

File Format: - Gzip-compressed JSON - Contains problem metadata and test cases - Binary extension (.bin) to prevent accidental editing

docs.title: Message Flow
docs.text: The UI sends a createProblem message to the extension, which then processes the request and creates the problem data structure.

docs.title: Configuration Options
docs.text:
This feature is affected by several settings that control problem creation behavior:

  • Time and Memory Limits: Configure default limits for new problems → See Problem Settings

  • File Storage: Choose where problem data files are stored → See Problem Settings

  • Templates: Use a template file for initializing new problem source files → See Problem Settings

docs.title: Common Errors
docs.text:
No Active Editor - Cause: No file is currently open - Message: "No active editor found. Please open a file to create a problem." - Solution: Open a source file and try again

Problem Already Exists - Cause: Problem file already exists for this source file - Message: "Problem already exists for this file" - Solution: Delete existing problem first or use a different file

Workspace Not Found - Cause: File is not in a workspace folder - Message: Problem creation fails silently - Solution: Open file in a workspace folder

docs.title: Implementation
docs.text: Error handling is implemented in the problem creation module with appropriate user feedback for each error condition.

docs.title: Typical Usage
docs.text:
1. Open a new C++ file: problem.cpp
  2. Click CREATE button in sidebar
  3. CPH-NG creates:
  4. Problem metadata with default limits
  5. Empty test cases array
  6. Binary file at .cph-ng/problem.cpp.bin
  7. Sidebar updates to show problem panel
  8. Ready to add test cases

docs.title: With Custom Settings
docs.text:
{
  "cph-ng.problem.defaultTimeLimit": 3000,
  "cph-ng.problem.defaultMemoryLimit": 1024
}

Result: New problem created with 3000ms time limit and 1024MB memory limit.

docs.title: Related Features
docs.text:
• Add Test Case - Add test cases after creation
  • Edit Problem - Modify problem metadata
  • Import Problem - Alternative creation method from CPH
  • Delete Problem - Remove created problem

docs.title: Delete Problem
docs.text: Remove a problem and its data from the workspace.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: The Delete Problem feature permanently removes the problem associated with the current source file. This deletes the problem file containing metadata and test cases, but does not affect your source code file.

docs.title: Triggering the Feature
docs.text: Method: Delete Button - Click the delete/trash icon button (rightmost button in the problem actions panel) - A confirmation dialog appears before deletion

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• A problem must be loaded for the current file
  • The problem panel must be visible

docs.title: UI Components
docs.text:
Delete Button: - Icon: Trash/delete icon - Color: Red (error color) to indicate destructive action - Position: Rightmost button in actions panel

Confirmation Dialog: - Title: Confirms deletion action - Content: Warns that action cannot be undone - Buttons: Cancel or Confirm

docs.title: How It Works
docs.text:
1. User Clicks Delete: Delete button is clicked
  2. Show Confirmation: Modal dialog asks for confirmation
  3. User Confirms: User clicks confirm button in dialog
  4. Delete File: Problem binary file is deleted from filesystem
  5. Remove from Memory: Problem is removed from active problems list
  6. Update UI: Sidebar returns to "no problem" state
  7. Preserve Source: Source code file remains untouched

docs.title: What Gets Deleted
docs.text:
• Problem metadata (name, URL, limits)
  • All test cases (inputs and outputs)
  • Problem configuration (SPJ, interactor settings)
  • Execution history and timing data
  • The .cph-ng/*.bin problem file

docs.title: What Is Preserved
docs.text:
• Source code file
  • Compiled executables (in cache)
  • Other problems in the workspace

docs.title: Confirmation Required
docs.text: Deletion requires explicit confirmation to prevent accidental data loss. The confirmation dialog clearly states that the action cannot be undone.

docs.title: Source Code Protected
docs.text: Only the problem metadata file is deleted. Your source code remains safe and unchanged.

docs.title: Deletion Failure
docs.text:
File Not Found: - Problem file may have been already deleted - Warning shown but operation continues

Permission Error: - Insufficient permissions to delete file - Error message displayed - Problem remains in system

docs.title: Removing Old Problem
docs.text:
1. Open file with problem you want to delete
  2. Problem panel shows in sidebar
  3. Click red delete/trash icon (rightmost button)
  4. Confirmation dialog appears: "Are you sure?"
  5. Click "Confirm" to proceed or "Cancel" to abort
  6. Problem is deleted
  7. Sidebar shows "no problem" state
  8. Source code file is unchanged

docs.title: After Deletion
docs.text:
• Can create a new problem for the same source file
  • Can import CPH data if available
  • All test runs and results are lost
  • Need to set up test cases again if recreating

docs.title: Related Features
docs.text:
• Create Problem - Create new problem after deletion
  • Import Problem - Import CPH data if available
  • Edit Problem - Alternative to deletion for fixing problems

docs.title: Delete Test Case
docs.text: Remove a specific test case from the problem.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: The Delete Test Case feature allows you to remove individual test cases from a problem. This is useful for cleaning up unwanted or redundant test cases.

docs.title: Triggering the Feature
docs.text: Method: Delete Icon - Locate the test case you want to delete - Hover over or click the test case to reveal controls - Click the delete/trash icon for that specific test case - No confirmation dialog - deletion is immediate

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• A problem must be loaded
  • At least one test case must exist

docs.title: UI Components
docs.text:
• Delete icon/button appears within each test case
  • Usually positioned in the test case header or controls area
  • Icon color typically indicates destructive action

docs.title: How It Works
docs.text:
1. User Clicks Delete: Delete icon clicked for specific test case
  2. Remove from Array: Test case removed from problem's test cases array
  3. Update Indices: Remaining test cases are re-indexed (#1, #2, etc.)
  4. Save: Problem file updated without the deleted test case
  5. Refresh UI: Test case list updates immediately

docs.title: What Gets Deleted
docs.text:
• Test case input data
  • Expected answer data
  • Test case execution results (if any)
  • The test case entry in the problem

docs.title: What Is Preserved
docs.text:
• Other test cases remain unchanged
  • Problem metadata unchanged
  • Source code unchanged

docs.title: No Confirmation
docs.text: Unlike problem deletion, test case deletion doesn't show a confirmation dialog. This allows quick cleanup of multiple test cases. Be careful when clicking delete icons.

docs.title: Removing Duplicate Test Case
docs.text:
1. Identify duplicate or unwanted test case
  2. Locate its delete icon
  3. Click delete icon
  4. Test case immediately removed
  5. Remaining test cases renumbered

docs.title: Cleaning Up After Import
docs.text: After importing test cases from files: 1. Review all imported cases 2. Identify unnecessary ones 3. Delete each unwanted case 4. Keep only relevant test cases

docs.title: Related Features
docs.text:
• Add Test Case - Add new test cases
  • Load Test Cases - Import multiple cases
  • Edit Test Case - Modify instead of deleting

docs.title: Edit Problem
docs.text: Modify problem metadata including title, URL, time limit, memory limit, and special judge settings.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: The Edit Problem feature allows you to modify various aspects of a problem after creation. You can change the problem name, URL, execution limits, and configure advanced features like Special Judge (SPJ) checkers and interactors for interactive problems.

docs.title: Triggering the Feature
docs.text: Method: Edit Button - Locate the pen/edit icon button in the problem title area (top-right corner) - Click the edit icon to open the edit dialog

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• A problem must be loaded for the current file
  • The problem panel must be visible in the sidebar

docs.title: UI Components
docs.text: Edit Dialog contains: - Title Field: Text input for problem name - URL Field: Text input for problem URL (optional) - Time Limit: Number input in milliseconds - Memory Limit: Number input in MB - Checker Section: Choose or remove Special Judge program - Interactor Section: Choose or remove interactor for interactive problems - Save/Cancel Buttons: Apply or discard changes

docs.title: How It Works
docs.text:
1. Open Dialog: Clicking edit button opens a modal dialog with current values
  2. Edit Fields: User modifies desired fields
  3. Validation: Basic validation on save (e.g., limits must be positive numbers)
  4. Update: Changes are applied to the problem data structure
  5. Save: Problem file is updated with new metadata
  6. Refresh: UI updates to show new values

docs.title: Editable Fields
docs.text:
Problem Metadata: - Name: Display name for the problem - URL: Link to online judge problem (if applicable) - Time Limit: Maximum execution time in milliseconds (e.g., 1000 = 1 second) - Memory Limit: Maximum memory usage in MB (e.g., 256 MB)

Advanced Options: - Checker: Special Judge program for custom output validation - Interactor: Program for interactive problem communication

docs.title: Default Limits
docs.text: When creating problems, defaults are used from settings. Editing allows overriding these:

docs.title: cph-ng.problem.defaultTimeLimit
docs.text:
• Type: number
  • Default: 1000 (milliseconds)
  • Note: Edit dialog allows changing per-problem

docs.title: cph-ng.problem.defaultMemoryLimit
docs.text:
• Type: number
  • Default: 512 (MB)
  • Note: Edit dialog allows changing per-problem

docs.title: Choosing a Checker
docs.text:
1. In edit dialog, click "Choose Checker" button
  2. Browse to select your compiled checker program
  3. Checker path is displayed
  4. Click "Remove Checker" to unset

Checker Requirements: - Must be a compiled executable - Should follow testlib.h conventions (recommended) - Receives input, output, and answer files as arguments

docs.title: Choosing an Interactor
docs.text:
1. In edit dialog, click "Choose Interactor" button
  2. Browse to select your compiled interactor program
  3. Interactor path is displayed
  4. Click "Remove Interactor" to unset

Interactor Requirements: - Must be a compiled executable - Communicates with solution via stdin/stdout - Used for interactive problems

docs.title: Validation Errors
docs.text:
Invalid Time Limit: - Time limit must be positive - Usually between 100ms and 10000ms

Invalid Memory Limit: - Memory limit must be positive - Usually between 16MB and 2048MB

Invalid Checker/Interactor Path: - File must exist - File must be executable - Must have correct extension for platform

docs.title: Changing Time Limit
docs.text:
1. Click edit icon in problem title area
  2. Edit dialog opens with current values
  3. Modify time limit field (e.g., change from 1000 to 2000)
  4. Click "Save" button
  5. Problem now uses 2000ms time limit for all test runs

docs.title: Adding Special Judge
docs.text:
1. Compile your checker program (e.g., checker.cpp → checker)
  2. Click edit icon
  3. In edit dialog, click "Choose Checker"
  4. Select your compiled checker executable
  5. Save changes
  6. Test cases now use your checker for validation

docs.title: Setting Up Interactive Problem
docs.text:
1. Compile your interactor program
  2. Click edit icon
  3. Click "Choose Interactor"
  4. Select your compiled interactor
  5. Save changes
  6. Problem now runs in interactive mode

docs.title: Related Features
docs.text:
• Create Problem - Initial problem setup with default limits
  • Special Judge - Detailed checker information
  • Interactive Problems - Interactor setup guide
  • Delete Problem - Remove problem if needed

docs.title: Edit Test Case
docs.text: Modify test case input and expected answer data.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: The Edit Test Case feature allows you to modify the input data and expected answer for individual test cases. You can edit inline data or switch between inline and file storage modes.

docs.title: Triggering the Feature
docs.text: Method: Direct Editing - Expand a test case by clicking on it - Click on input or answer fields to edit - Type or paste your data - Changes save automatically

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• A problem must be loaded
  • Test case must exist in the problem

docs.title: UI Components
docs.text: Each test case displays: - Input Field: Editable text area for test input - Answer Field: Editable text area for expected output - Auto-save: Changes are saved when you click away or modify content

docs.title: How It Works
docs.text:
1. Expand Test Case: User clicks on test case to expand it
  2. Edit Field: User clicks on input or answer field
  3. Type Data: User enters or modifies data
  4. Auto-save: On blur or change, data is saved
  5. Update Problem: Problem file is updated with new data
  6. Refresh UI: Test case displays updated content

docs.title: Data Modes
docs.text:
Inline Mode: - Data stored directly in problem file - Suitable for small to medium sized data - Easy to edit directly in UI

File Mode: - Data stored in external files - Better for large test data - Files named systematically

docs.title: cph-ng.problem.maxInlineDataLength
docs.text:
• Type: number
  • Default: 65536 (bytes)
  • Description: Maximum size for inline data
  • Note: Data exceeding this is automatically converted to file storage

docs.title: Text Input
docs.text:
• Paste from clipboard
  • Type manually
  • Multi-line support
  • Preserves formatting and whitespace

docs.title: Large Data Handling
docs.text: If data exceeds the inline limit: - Automatically converted to file storage - File icon shown instead of inline editor - Can still view/edit through file

docs.title: Modifying Input Data
docs.text:
1. Locate test case in problem panel
  2. Click to expand the test case
  3. Click on "Input" section
  4. Modify the input data: 
    3 5
1 2 3
  5. Click elsewhere or press Tab
  6. Changes are saved automatically

docs.title: Updating Expected Answer
docs.text:
1. Expand test case
  2. Click on "Answer" section
  3. Update expected output: 
    8
  4. Data saves automatically
  5. Next test run will use new answer for comparison

docs.title: Correcting Wrong Answer
docs.text: After running a test and seeing WA: 1. Review actual output 2. If expected answer was wrong, click on answer field 3. Update with correct expected output 4. Can also click "Set as Answer" button to use actual output

docs.title: Related Features
docs.text:
• Add Test Case - Create new test cases to edit
  • Toggle File/Inline - Switch storage mode
  • Compare Output - View differences when testing
  • Delete Test Case - Remove unwanted cases

docs.title: Import Problem
docs.text: Import a problem from the original CPH extension format.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: The Import Problem feature allows you to migrate problems from the original CPH (Competitive Programming Helper) extension to CPH-NG. It reads the CPH problem file associated with your source code and converts it to CPH-NG's format with all test cases and metadata.

docs.title: Triggering the Feature
docs.text:
Method 1: Sidebar Button - Open a source file that has an associated CPH problem file - Click the IMPORT button in the CPH-NG sidebar panel - The button only appears when CPH problem data is detected

Method 2: Command Palette - Press Ctrl+Shift+P (Windows/Linux) or Cmd+Shift+P (macOS) - Type and select: CPH-NG: Import Problem

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• A source file must be active in the editor
  • A CPH problem file (.prob) must exist for that source file
  • No CPH-NG problem should already exist for this file
  • The CPH problem file must be in valid format

docs.title: UI Components
docs.text: The import option appears as: - An IMPORT button with input icon in the create problem view - Only displayed when CPH data is detected for the current file - Styled as a contained (filled) button to draw attention

docs.title: How It Works
docs.text:
1. Detection: Checks if a CPH problem file exists for the active source file
  2. Validation:
  3. Verifies no CPH-NG problem already exists
  4. Checks if source file path is valid
  5. Loading: Reads and parses the CPH problem file
  6. Conversion: Converts CPH data format to CPH-NG format:
  7. Problem name and metadata
  8. Time and memory limits
  9. Test cases (input and expected output)
  10. Problem URL if available
  11. Storage: Saves converted problem in CPH-NG format
  12. UI Update: Refreshes the sidebar to show the imported problem

docs.title: CPH File Location
docs.text: CPH stores problem data in .cph folder with filenames based on the source file. CPH-NG automatically locates these files when checking for import availability.

docs.title: cph-ng.problem.problemFilePath
docs.text:
• Type: string
  • Default: "${workspace}/.cph-ng/${relativeDirname}/${basename}.bin"
  • Description: Where imported problems are stored in CPH-NG format
  • Note: Imported problems are saved to this location after conversion

docs.title: Common Errors
docs.text:
No Active Editor - Cause: No file is currently open - Message: "No active editor found. Please open a file to create a problem." - Solution: Open a source file and try again

Problem Already Exists - Cause: CPH-NG problem already exists for this file - Message: "Problem already exists for this file" - Solution: Delete existing CPH-NG problem first or use a different file

No CPH Data Found - Cause: No CPH problem file exists for the source file - Message: Import button is hidden - Solution: Use Create Problem instead, or ensure CPH data exists

Invalid CPH File - Cause: CPH file is corrupted or in wrong format - Message: Import fails silently or shows error - Solution: Check CPH file integrity or recreate from scratch

docs.title: Migrating from CPH
docs.text:
1. Open a file that has CPH problem data (e.g., solution.cpp)
  2. CPH-NG detects the .cph/solution.cpp.prob file
  3. The IMPORT button appears in the sidebar
  4. Click IMPORT button
  5. CPH-NG converts and imports:
  6. Problem metadata
  7. All test cases
  8. Time/memory limits
  9. Sidebar updates to show the imported problem
  10. Test cases are immediately available for running

docs.title: After Import
docs.text:
• Original CPH file remains unchanged
  • Problem is now in CPH-NG format
  • Can use all CPH-NG features with imported problem
  • Test cases maintain their data (input/output)

docs.title: Related Features
docs.text:
• Create Problem - Alternative if no CPH data exists
  • Edit Problem - Modify imported problem metadata
  • CPH Import - Batch import from CPH using command

docs.title: Features
docs.text: CPH-NG provides comprehensive features for competitive programming. Each feature is documented in detail below.

docs.title: Problem Management
docs.text:
• Create Problem - Create a new competitive programming problem
  • Import Problem - Import problem from CPH format
  • Edit Problem - Modify problem metadata and settings
  • Delete Problem - Remove a problem from workspace

docs.title: Test Case Management
docs.text:
• Add Test Case - Manually add a single test case
  • Load Test Cases - Import test cases from files or folders
  • Edit Test Case - Modify test case data
  • Delete Test Case - Remove a test case
  • Toggle File/Inline - Switch between file and inline data display
  • Compare Output - View diff between actual and expected output

docs.title: Running and Testing
docs.text:
• Run Single Test Case - Execute one test case
  • Run All Test Cases - Execute all test cases sequentially
  • Stop Execution - Terminate running test cases
  • Clear Results - Reset test case execution results

docs.title: Advanced Features
docs.text:
• Brute Force Compare - Find edge cases using brute force comparison
  • Special Judge - Use custom checker programs for validation
  • Interactive Problems - Support for interactive problems
  • Submit to Codeforces - Direct submission to Codeforces

docs.title: Integration
docs.text:
• Competitive Companion Integration - Browser extension integration
  • CPH Import - Import data from original CPH extension

docs.title: Interactive Problems
docs.text: Support for interactive problems with custom interactor programs.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: Interactive problems require two-way communication between your solution and a judge program. Your solution reads queries, processes them, and writes responses, with the interactor validating the interaction.

docs.title: Setup
docs.text:
1. Click edit icon in problem title
  2. Find "Interactor" section in edit dialog
  3. Click "Choose Interactor"
  4. Select compiled interactor executable
  5. Save changes

docs.title: Requirements
docs.text:
• Interactor must be compiled executable
  • Communicates via stdin/stdout
  • Manages the interaction protocol

docs.title: How It Works
docs.text: With interactor configured: 1. Your solution starts 2. Interactor starts simultaneously 3. Solution writes query → Interactor reads 4. Interactor writes response → Solution reads 5. Continues until solution outputs answer or error 6. Interactor determines verdict

docs.title: Example Interaction
docs.text:
Problem: Guess a number between 1-100

Your Solution: 

while(true) {
    cout << guess << endl;
    cout.flush();
    string response;
    cin >> response;
    if (response == "CORRECT") break;
    // adjust guess based on response
}

Interactor: Provides "HIGHER"/"LOWER"/"CORRECT" responses

docs.title: Related Features
docs.text:
• Edit Problem - Configure interactor
  • Special Judge - Alternative validation

docs.title: Load Test Cases
docs.text: Import test cases from zip files or folders.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: The Load Test Cases feature allows you to import multiple test cases at once from external sources. It supports loading from zip archives or directory folders, automatically matching input (.in) files with answer (.out, .ans) files.

docs.title: Triggering the Feature
docs.text: Method: Sidebar Button - Click the folder/file copy icon button in the problem actions panel - Located as second button from left below problem title

docs.title: UI Components
docs.text: Button properties: - Icon: File/folder icon - Label: Localized "Load Test Cases" text - Position: Second button from left in action panel

docs.title: How It Works
docs.text:
The load process follows these steps:

  1. Source Selection: Shows dialog with options:
  2. Load from a zip file

  3. Load from a folder

  4. File/Folder Selection:

  5. For zip: Prompts user to choose a zip file
  6. For folder: Prompts user to choose a directory

  7. Zip files are extracted to a temporary folder

  8. Test Case Discovery:

  9. Scans all files recursively in the selected location
  10. Matches .in files with corresponding .out or .ans files by name

  11. Orders test cases naturally (test1, test2, test10, etc.)

  12. Test Case Selection:

  13. Displays all discovered test cases in a selection dialog
  14. Shows input and answer file paths for each case

  15. User can select which cases to import

  16. Import:

  17. Adds selected test cases to the problem
  18. Optionally clears existing test cases first (based on settings)
  19. Updates UI to show imported cases

docs.title: Configuration Options
docs.text:
This feature is affected by several settings:

  • Folder Selection: Choose how folder picker works → See Basic Settings

  • Zip Handling: Control where zips extract and if they're deleted → See Problem Settings

  • Test Case Clearing: Choose whether to keep or replace existing test cases → See Problem Settings

docs.title: Loading from Zip
docs.text:
1. Click load test cases button
  2. Select "Load from a zip file"
  3. Choose zip file from file system
  4. Zip extracts to .cph-ng/{zipname}/
  5. Found test cases are displayed
  6. Select which ones to import
  7. Test cases added to problem

docs.title: Loading from Folder
docs.text:
1. Click load test cases button
  2. Select "Load from a folder"
  3. Choose folder with test files
  4. Files scanned for .in/.out pairs
  5. Matching pairs shown in selection dialog
  6. Select test cases to import
  7. Test cases added to problem

docs.title: Related Features
docs.text:
• Add Test Case - Manual single case addition
  • Edit Test Case - Modify imported cases
  • Toggle File/Inline - Switch data storage mode

docs.title: File Matching Rules
docs.text:
CPH-NG matches input and answer files by their base names:

Input Files: Must have .in extension (e.g., test1.in, sample01.in) Answer Files: Can have .out or .ans extension (e.g., test1.out, sample01.ans) Matching: test1.in matches with test1.out or test1.ans

Files without matches are still imported (input only, no expected answer).

docs.title: Run All Test Cases
docs.text: Execute all test cases sequentially and display results.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: The Run All Test Cases feature executes your solution against every test case in sequence, displaying results for each. This is the primary way to validate your solution comprehensively before submission.

docs.title: Triggering the Feature
docs.text:
Method 1: Run All Button - Click the run all/playlist icon in the problem actions panel - All test cases execute in order

Method 2: Keyboard Shortcut - Press the configured shortcut (check settings) - All tests run immediately

Method 3: Right-click Menu - Right-click on the run all button - Choose compilation mode: - Force Compile - Skip Compile - Auto (default)

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• Problem must be loaded
  • Source file must be saved
  • At least one test case must exist

docs.title: UI Components
docs.text:
Run All Button: - Icon: Playlist play icon - Color: Green (success color) - Position: Third or fourth button in actions panel

Progress Indicator: - Shows which test is currently running - Updates as each test completes - Can stop execution mid-run

docs.title: How It Works
docs.text:
1. Pre-execution:
  2. Check if source file is saved
  3. Determine if compilation needed

  4. Compile once for all tests

  5. Sequential Execution:

  6. Run test #1, capture results
  7. Run test #2, capture results
  8. Continue for all tests

  9. Each test independent

  10. Result Collection:

  11. Collect verdicts for all tests
  12. Calculate total execution time

  13. Track pass/fail count

  14. Display Summary:

  15. Update each test case with result
  16. Show overall statistics
  17. Highlight failures

docs.title: Execution Order
docs.text:
• Tests run in the order they appear
  • Execution stops if user clicks stop
  • Failed tests don't prevent subsequent tests
  • Each test gets fresh execution environment

docs.title: Compilation
docs.text: Same compilation settings as single test (see Run Single Test).

docs.title: cph-ng.runner.timeAddition
docs.text: • Applied to each test case individually

docs.title: cph-ng.problem.timeLimit
docs.text:
• Each test case uses the problem's time limit
  • Tests don't share a time budget

docs.title: Stopping Execution
docs.text: Two ways to stop: 1. Stop All: Click stop button (stops after current test) 2. Stop Current Only: Ctrl+Click stop button (skips to next test)

docs.title: Complete Validation
docs.text:
1. Write solution
  2. Add/load all test cases
  3. Click "Run All" button
  4. Watch tests execute:
  9. Fix issue causing #3 to fail
  10. Run all again
  11. All tests pass (AC)

docs.title: Quick Iteration
docs.text:
1. Make code change
  2. Run all tests
  3. Most pass, one TLE
  4. Optimize algorithm
  5. Run all again
  6. All pass now

docs.title: Early Stopping
docs.text:
1. Run all tests
  2. Test #2 fails
  3. Don't want to wait for remaining 10 tests
  4. Click stop button
  5. Fix the issue
  6. Run all again from start

docs.title: Result Summary
docs.text: After running all tests: - Total tests: 5 - Passed (AC): 4 - Failed (WA, TLE, etc.): 1 - Total time: 127ms - Status: FAILED (if any test failed)

docs.title: Related Features
docs.text:
• Run Single Test - Test individual cases
  • Stop Execution - Cancel running tests
  • Clear Results - Reset all results
  • Compare Output - Debug failures

docs.title: Run Single Test Case
docs.text: Execute one test case and display results.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: The Run Single Test Case feature allows you to run your solution against a specific test case. This is useful for debugging individual cases or testing specific scenarios without running all test cases.

docs.title: Triggering the Feature
docs.text:
Method 1: Run Button - Expand a test case - Click the run/play icon for that specific test case - Test executes immediately

Method 2: Right-click Menu - Right-click on a test case - Select run option from context menu - Choose compilation mode (force compile or skip compile)

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• A problem must be loaded
  • Source file must be saved
  • Test case must exist with at least input data

docs.title: UI Components
docs.text:
Run Button: - Icon: Play/triangle icon - Position: Within each test case - Click to run that specific case

Compilation Options (via menu): - Force Compile: Always recompile before running - Skip Compile: Use cached binary if available - Auto (Ctrl+Click): Smart compilation based on changes

docs.title: How It Works
docs.text:
1. Compilation:
  2. Check if recompilation needed
  3. Compile source if necessary (or forced)
  4. Use cached binary if available and valid

  5. Handle compilation errors

  6. Execution:

  7. Create temporary input file or pipe
  8. Run compiled program with test input
  9. Capture stdout, stderr
  10. Measure execution time and memory
  11. Apply time and memory limits

  12. Handle timeouts and crashes

  13. Comparison:

  14. Compare actual output with expected answer
  15. Determine verdict (AC, WA, TLE, MLE, RE, etc.)

  16. Calculate differences if WA

  17. Display Results:

  18. Update test case UI with verdict
  19. Show execution time and memory
  20. Display output or error messages
  21. Enable comparison if WA

docs.title: Verdict Types
docs.text:
• AC (Accepted): Output matches expected
  • WA (Wrong Answer): Output differs from expected
  • TLE (Time Limit Exceeded): Exceeded time limit
  • MLE (Memory Limit Exceeded): Exceeded memory limit
  • RE (Runtime Error): Program crashed
  • CE (Compilation Error): Failed to compile
  • PE (Presentation Error): Whitespace differences only
  • OLE (Output Limit Exceeded): Output too large
  • And others (see full list in comparing settings)

docs.title: Configuration Options
docs.text:
This feature is affected by multiple configuration settings:

  • Compilation: Control compiler, arguments, and timeouts → See Compilation Settings

  • Execution: Control resource measurement and time additions → See Runner Settings

  • Comparison: Control how output is compared and verdicts determined → See Comparing Settings

  • Caching: Speed up repeated compilations → See Cache Settings

docs.title: Basic Test Run
docs.text:
1. Write solution code
  2. Save file
  3. Expand test case #1
  4. Click run button
  5. See results:
  6. ✅ #1 AC (15ms, 3.2MB)
  7. Output matches expected answer

docs.title: Debugging TLE
docs.text:
1. Run test case
  2. Result: TLE after 1000ms
  3. Review code for infinite loops or inefficiency
  4. Optimize algorithm
  5. Re-run test case
  6. Result: AC (250ms)

docs.title: Handling Compilation Error
docs.text:
1. Click run
  2. Result: CE
  3. Compilation output shows error
  4. Fix syntax error in code
  5. Save file
  6. Re-run (automatically recompiles)

docs.title: Testing with Custom Input
docs.text:
1. Add new test case
  2. Enter specific input to test edge case
  3. Enter expected output (if known)
  4. Run the test
  5. Verify behavior

docs.title: Related Features
docs.text:
• Run All Tests - Execute all test cases
  • Stop Execution - Cancel running test
  • Clear Results - Reset test results
  • Compare Output - View differences for WA

docs.title: Special Judge
docs.text: Use custom checker programs for non-standard answer validation.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: Special Judge (SPJ) allows problems with multiple correct answers or custom validation logic. Instead of exact output matching, your checker program validates whether the output is correct according to problem requirements.

docs.title: Setup
docs.text:
1. Click edit icon in problem title
  2. In edit dialog, find "Checker" section
  3. Click "Choose Checker"
  4. Select compiled checker executable
  5. Save changes

docs.title: Requirements
docs.text:
• Checker must be compiled executable
  • Should follow testlib.h conventions (recommended)
  • Receives test input, contestant output, and expected answer as arguments

docs.title: How It Works
docs.text: When SPJ is configured: 1. Your solution runs normally 2. Instead of direct comparison, checker is invoked 3. Checker receives: input file, output file, answer file 4. Checker exits with code: 0 (AC), 1 (WA), or other 5. Verdict determined by checker's exit code

docs.title: Checker Program Structure
docs.text:
Typical checker (C++ with testlib.h): 

#include "testlib.h"
int main(int argc, char* argv[]) {
    registerTestlibCmd(argc, argv);
    int expected = ans.readInt();
    int output = ouf.readInt();
    if (output == expected)
        quitf(_ok, "Correct");
    else
        quitf(_wa, "Wrong answer");
}

docs.title: Related Features
docs.text:
• Edit Problem - Configure SPJ
  • Interactive Problems - Alternative for two-way communication

docs.title: Stop Execution
docs.text: Terminate currently running test cases.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: The Stop Execution feature allows you to cancel test cases that are running. This is useful when a test takes too long, is stuck in an infinite loop, or when you realize you need to make changes before the tests finish.

docs.title: Triggering the Feature
docs.text:
Method 1: Stop Button - While tests are running, the run button changes to a stop button - Click to stop execution after current test completes

Method 2: Stop Only Current (Ctrl+Click) - Ctrl+Click (or Cmd+Click on macOS) the stop button - Stops the current test immediately - Proceeds to next test case

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• Tests must be currently running
  • Stop button only appears during execution

docs.title: UI Components
docs.text: Stop Button: - Icon: Stop/square icon - Color: Orange/warning color - Replaces run button during execution - Click: Stop after current test - Ctrl+Click: Skip current test

docs.title: How It Works
docs.text:
Normal Stop (Click): 1. User clicks stop button 2. Current test continues to completion 3. After current test finishes, remaining tests cancelled 4. Results shown for completed tests 5. Incomplete tests show no result

Skip Current (Ctrl+Click): 1. User Ctrl+clicks stop button 2. Current test process is terminated immediately 3. Next test starts running 4. Useful for skipping stuck tests

docs.title: Process Termination
docs.text: When stopping: - Running process receives termination signal - Process cleanup handled gracefully - Temporary files cleaned up - UI returns to ready state

docs.title: Stopping Infinite Loop
docs.text:
1. Run all tests
  2. Test #3 runs forever (infinite loop)
  3. Realize the bug
  4. Click stop button
  5. Test #3 eventually times out or click Ctrl+Click to skip
  6. Fix code
  7. Run again

docs.title: Quick Iteration During Development
docs.text:
1. Start running all 20 tests
  2. After 5 tests, notice a pattern in failures
  3. Don't want to wait for remaining 15 tests
  4. Click stop
  5. Current test finishes
  6. Execution stops
  7. Make fixes based on first 5 results

docs.title: Skipping Slow Test
docs.text:
1. Running all tests
  2. Test #8 is very slow (legitimate, not a bug)
  3. Want to skip it for now
  4. Ctrl+Click stop when test #8 is running
  5. Test #8 terminated
  6. Test #9 starts immediately

docs.title: Related Features
docs.text:
• Run Single Test - Run one test at a time
  • Run All Tests - What stop interrupts
  • Clear Results - Clean up after stopping

docs.title: Submit to Codeforces
docs.text: Direct submission to Codeforces online judge.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: Submit to Codeforces feature allows you to submit your solution directly to Codeforces from within VS Code, without opening a browser.

docs.title: Triggering
docs.text: Submit Button: - Only appears when problem URL is from Codeforces - Icon: Upload/backup icon - Color: Green (success) - Click to start submission

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• Problem must have valid Codeforces URL
  • Must be logged into Codeforces in browser
  • Source file must be saved

docs.title: How It Works
docs.text:
1. Click submit button
  2. Extension extracts contest/problem IDs from URL
  3. Opens browser for authentication
  4. Submits code to Codeforces
  5. Confirmation shown

docs.title: cph-ng.companion.submitLanguage
docs.text:
• Selects C++ compiler version for Codeforces
  • Options: GCC, Clang, MSVC versions

docs.title: Related Features
docs.text:
• Edit Problem - Set problem URL
  • Competitive Companion - Auto-import from Codeforces

docs.title: Toggle File/Inline
docs.text: Switch test case data between file storage and inline display modes.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: The Toggle File/Inline feature allows you to change how test case data is stored and displayed. Small data can be shown inline for easy viewing and editing, while large data can be stored in external files for better performance.

docs.title: Triggering the Feature
docs.text: Method: Toggle Button - Expand a test case - Locate the file/inline toggle icon (usually near input or answer fields) - Click to switch between modes: - Inline → File: Saves data to external file - File → Inline: Loads data from file into inline editor

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• A problem must be loaded
  • Test case must exist
  • For inline mode: Data size should be within limits

docs.title: UI Components
docs.text:
Toggle Icons: - File icon: Indicates data is in file mode - Inline icon: Indicates data is in inline mode - Click to switch between modes

Warning for Large Data: - If file data is very large, warning shown before converting to inline - User can proceed or cancel

docs.title: How It Works
docs.text:
Toggling to File Mode: 1. User clicks toggle button on inline data 2. Data extracted from inline field 3. Unique filename generated 4. Data written to file 5. Test case updated to reference file 6. UI shows file icon with filename

Toggling to Inline Mode: 1. User clicks toggle button on file data 2. Check file size against limit 3. If too large, show warning 4. If user proceeds or size OK, read file 5. Load data into inline field 6. Test case updated to inline mode 7. UI shows editable text field

docs.title: File Naming
docs.text: Files are named systematically: - Input files: input_{index}.txt or similar - Answer files: answer_{index}.txt or similar - Stored in cache or problem-specific folder

docs.title: cph-ng.problem.maxInlineDataLength
docs.text:
• Type: number
  • Default: 65536 (bytes)
  • Description: Maximum size for inline data
  • Warning: Attempting to inline larger data shows warning

docs.title: cph-ng.runner.stdoutThreshold
docs.text:
• Type: number
  • Default: 65536 (bytes)
  • Description: Output size threshold (similar concept)

docs.title: Use Inline Mode For:
docs.text:
• Small test inputs/outputs
  • Frequently edited data
  • Quick viewing and modification
  • Test cases you want to see at a glance

docs.title: Use File Mode For:
docs.text:
• Large test data (> 64KB)
  • Binary or special character data
  • Performance optimization
  • Data that rarely changes

docs.title: Converting Large Data to File
docs.text:
1. Test case has very long input inline
  2. UI is slow or cluttered
  3. Click toggle button
  4. Data automatically saved to file
  5. UI now shows just filename
  6. Can still run tests normally

docs.title: Loading File Data for Quick Edit
docs.text:
1. Test case input is in file mode
  2. Need to quickly edit a value
  3. Click toggle button
  4. If data not too large, loads inline
  5. Edit directly in UI
  6. Changes save to problem

docs.title: Handling Large File Warning
docs.text:
1. Click toggle on large file
  2. Warning appears: "File is very large (800KB)"
  3. Options: "Yes" to proceed or "Cancel"
  4. If Yes: Data loads inline (may be slow)
  5. If Cancel: Remains in file mode

docs.title: Related Features
docs.text:
• Edit Test Case - Edit data in either mode
  • Load Test Cases - Imported data mode depends on size
  • Add Test Case - New cases start in inline mode

docs.title: 什么是 CPH-NG？
docs.text:
CPH-NG（Competitive Programming Helper - Next Generation，竞争性编程助手 - 新一代）是一个用于竞争性编程的 VS Code 扩展。它帮助您在本地编译、运行和评测您的解决方案，测试用例可以从在线评测网站导入或手动创建。

查看概述了解更多信息。

docs.title: CPH-NG 与原版 CPH 有何不同？
docs.text:
CPH-NG 是一个完全重写的版本，包含许多增强功能：

  • 更多的评测状态（21 种 vs 3 种）
  • 编译缓存以加快测试速度
  • 支持从文件和文件夹加载测试用例
  • 特殊评测（SPJ）和交互式问题支持
  • 暴力对拍
  • 更好的内存管理

查看 README 中的对比表。

docs.title: CPH-NG 支持哪些语言？
docs.text:
目前，CPH-NG 支持：

  • C++（推荐用于竞争性编程）
  • C
  • Java

未来版本可能会添加更多语言。

docs.title: 在哪里可以下载 CPH-NG？
docs.text:
直接从 VS Code 安装：

  1. 打开 VS Code
  2. 转到扩展（Ctrl/Cmd+Shift+X）
  3. 搜索"CPH NG"
  4. 点击安装

或使用此直接链接：安装 CPH-NG

docs.title: 如何配置我的编译器？
docs.text:
1. 打开 VS Code 设置（Ctrl/Cmd+,）
  2. 搜索"cph-ng compilation"
  3. 配置编译器路径和标志

查看编译设置了解详情。

docs.title: 可以使用自定义代码模板吗？
docs.text:
可以！在设置中设置模板文件路径：

{
  "cph-ng.problem.templateFile": "/path/to/your/template.cpp"
}

查看问题设置了解更多选项。

docs.title: 如何创建新问题？
docs.text:
三种方式：

  1. 点击侧边栏中的"CREATE"
  2. 使用命令面板：CPH-NG: Create Problem
  3. 使用键盘快捷键：Ctrl+Alt+B（macOS 上为 Cmd+Alt+B）

查看快速入门了解详情。

docs.title: 如何从在线评测网站导入问题？
docs.text:
1. 安装 Competitive Companion 浏览器扩展
  2. 转到支持的评测网站上的问题（Codeforces、AtCoder 等）
  3. 点击 Competitive Companion 图标
  4. CPH-NG 将自动创建带有测试用例的问题

查看功能指南 - Competitive Companion了解配置选项。

docs.title: 如何从文件加载测试用例？
docs.text:
1. 点击问题面板中的文件夹图标
  2. 选择"从 zip 文件加载"或"从文件夹加载"
  3. 选择您的文件/文件夹
  4. 选择要导入的测试用例

CPH-NG 自动按名称匹配 .in 文件与 .out/.ans 文件。

查看功能指南 - 从文件加载了解详情。

docs.title: 为什么我的程序无法编译？
docs.text:
常见问题：

  1. 找不到编译器：检查设置中的编译器路径
  2. 编译超时：在编译设置中增加超时时间
  3. 语法错误：查看编译输出面板

docs.title: 为什么我的解决方案应该通过却得到 TLE？
docs.text:
可能的原因：

  1. 机器较慢：在运行器设置中增加 timeAddition
  2. 实际的无限循环：检查您的代码逻辑
  3. 时间限制过于严格：编辑问题元数据以增加时间限制

docs.title: 如何使用特殊评测？
docs.text:
1. 编写检查器程序（使用 testlib.h 或自定义）
  2. 编译您的检查器
  3. 点击笔形图标编辑问题元数据
  4. 点击"Choose Checker"并选择您编译的检查器

查看功能指南 - 特殊评测了解要求和示例。

docs.title: 什么是暴力对拍？
docs.text:
暴力对拍通过以下方式帮助找到边界情况：

  1. 生成随机测试输入
  2. 同时运行您的优化解法和暴力参考解法
  3. 比较输出直到它们不同
  4. 将失败的用例保存为测试用例

查看功能指南 - 暴力对拍了解设置说明。

docs.title: 编译缓存如何工作？
docs.text:
CPH-NG 计算源代码和编译器设置的哈希值。如果自上次编译以来没有任何变化，它会重用缓存的二进制文件，节省时间。

这是自动的，不需要配置。

docs.title: 可以自定义存储问题的文件夹吗？
docs.text:
可以！在设置中配置路径模式：

{
  "cph-ng.problem.problemFilePath": "${workspace}/.cph-ng/${basename}.bin"
}

查看问题设置了解可用变量。

docs.title: 如何隐藏某些评测状态？
docs.text:
在设置中配置隐藏状态：

{
  "cph-ng.sidebar.hiddenStatuses": ["WT", "FC", "CP", "CPD"]
}

查看侧边栏设置了解完整的状态代码列表。

docs.title: 侧边栏面板未显示
docs.text:
1. 检查 CPH-NG 图标是否在活动栏中
  2. 点击图标打开面板
  3. 如果仍未显示，尝试重新加载 VS Code（Ctrl/Cmd+Shift+P → "Developer: Reload Window"）

docs.title: 测试用例无法运行
docs.text:
1. 确保文件已保存
  2. 检查编译是否成功
  3. 在编译输出面板中查找错误
  4. 验证编译器设置是否正确

docs.title: 内存测量不准确
docs.text:
启用高级运行器：

{
  "cph-ng.runner.useRunner": true
}

注意：可能需要额外的系统权限。

查看运行器设置了解详情。

docs.title: 输出太大无法显示
docs.text:
大输出会自动保存到文件。您可以：

  1. 点击文件名查看内容
  2. 使用文件图标在文件和内联显示之间切换
  3. 在运行器设置中调整阈值

docs.title: 在 Linux/macOS 上遇到权限错误
docs.text:
某些功能可能需要：

  1. 编译器的可执行权限
  2. 缓存目录的写入权限
  3. 在工作区中创建文件的权限

检查您的系统权限和文件所有权。

docs.title: 在哪里报告错误？
docs.text:
在 GitHub Issues 上报告错误。

请包含：

  • 您的操作系统和 VS Code 版本
  • CPH-NG 版本
  • 重现步骤
  • 错误消息或屏幕截图

docs.title: 在哪里请求功能？
docs.text: 欢迎在 GitHub Discussions 上提出功能请求。

docs.title: 如何贡献？
docs.text: 欢迎贡献！查看关于页面了解如何贡献的信息。

docs.title: 在哪里可以找到源代码？
docs.text: CPH-NG 是开源的：GitHub 仓库

docs.title: 其他资源
docs.text:
• 功能指南 - 所有功能的全面指南
  • 配置参考 - 所有配置选项
  • 快速入门 - 快速开始
  • 模块 - 额外功能
  • 关于 - 项目信息

docs.title: CPH-NG
docs.text:
CPH NG（Competitive Programming Helper - Next Generation，竞争性编程助手 - 新一代）是一个专为竞争性编程开发的 Visual Studio Code (VS Code) 扩展。

CPH NG 使用户能够在 VS Code 环境中方便高效地编译、运行和评测程序。

注意

目前 CPH NG 仅支持 C++ 和 Java。

docs.title: 什么是 CPH-NG？
docs.text: CPH-NG 是 Competitive Programming Helper 的下一代版本，为在 VS Code 中工作的竞争性程序员提供全面的解决方案。无论您是在在线评测网站上练习还是处理自己的问题，CPH-NG 都能简化从问题创建到提交的整个工作流程。

docs.title: 🎯 智能测试数据管理
docs.text:
提供多种灵活的方式导入测试数据：

  • 从 Competitive Companion 浏览器扩展导入
  • 从 zip 文件或目录加载
  • 手动创建测试用例
  • 从 CPH 格式导入
  • 从源文件中的嵌入数据加载

docs.title: ⚡ 智能编译系统
docs.text:
CPH-NG 具有智能编译系统，能够：

  • 检测文件更改，仅在必要时重新编译
  • 缓存已编译的二进制文件以加快测试速度
  • 支持自定义编译器标志和优化级别
  • 提供清晰的编译错误消息
  • 支持编译钩子和包装器

docs.title: 📊 全面的评测系统
docs.text:
CPH-NG 支持 21 种不同的评测状态：

  • AC（Accepted，通过）- 您的解决方案正确
  • PC（Partially Correct，部分正确）- 部分测试用例通过
  • PE（Presentation Error，格式错误）- 输出格式不正确
  • WA（Wrong Answer，答案错误）- 输出不正确
  • TLE（Time Limit Exceeded，超时）- 执行时间过长
  • MLE（Memory Limit Exceeded，内存超限）- 使用内存过多
  • OLE（Output Limit Exceeded，输出超限）- 生成输出过多
  • RE（Runtime Error，运行时错误）- 程序执行过程中崩溃
  • RF（Restricted Function，受限函数）- 使用了禁止的系统调用
  • CE（Compilation Error，编译错误）- 编译失败
  • SE（System Error，系统错误）- 内部评测错误
  • 以及更多...

docs.title: 🎓 特殊评测支持
docs.text:
CPH-NG 完全支持：

  • 使用 testlib.h 或自定义检查器的特殊评测（SPJ）程序
  • 带有自定义交互器的交互式问题
  • 针对非标准输出格式的灵活问题验证

docs.title: 🔄 高级功能
docs.text:
• 暴力对拍：使用暴力参考解法测试您的优化解决方案
  • 文件/内联切换：在内联数据和外部文件之间切换以处理大型测试用例
  • 耗时跟踪：监控您在问题上工作的时间
  • 答案比较视图：错误答案的可视化差异对比
  • 结果持久化：跨会话保持测试结果的记录

docs.title: 安装
docs.text:
从 Visual Studio Code 市场直接安装 CPH-NG：

安装 CPH-NG

或在 VS Code 扩展面板中搜索"CPH NG"。

docs.title: 基本设置
docs.text: 控制 UI 行为和文件夹选择方法的常规设置。

docs.title: cph-ng.basic.folderOpener
docs.text:
控制对话框中用于选择文件夹的方法。

  • 类型：字符串枚举（"default" | "native"）
  • 默认值："default"
  • 用户影响：
  • "default"：使用 VS Code 的标准文件夹选择器（在包括远程开发在内的所有环境中都可用）
  • "native"：使用系统原生文件夹对话框（在本地系统上可能提供更好的用户体验，但在远程/Web 环境中不可用）

示例： 

{
  "cph-ng.basic.folderOpener": "native"
}

从文件夹加载测试用例时，将使用系统的原生文件夹选择器而不是 VS Code 的对话框。

docs.title: 何时更改此设置
docs.text:
• 使用 "default"：如果您使用远程开发（SSH、WSL、容器），或在文件夹选择时遇到问题
  • 使用 "native"：如果您喜欢操作系统的文件夹选择器并且仅处理本地文件

docs.title: 相关功能
docs.text: • 加载测试用例 - 从文件夹加载时使用文件夹选择

docs.title: 暴力对拍设置
docs.text: 自动查找失败测试用例的暴力对拍功能的设置。

docs.title: 概述
docs.text: 暴力对拍通过以下方式帮助您查找边界情况： 1. 运行生成器创建随机输入 2. 在这些输入上运行您的解法 3. 运行已知正确的暴力解法 4. 比较输出以查找差异

docs.title: cph-ng.bfCompare.generatorTimeLimit
docs.text:
允许测试用例生成器运行的最长时间（以毫秒为单位）。

  • 类型：数字
  • 默认值：3000（3 秒）
  • 用户影响：如果生成器生成测试用例所需时间超过此值，它将被终止。如果您的生成器需要更多时间生成复杂的测试用例，请增加此值。

示例： 

{
  "cph-ng.bfCompare.generatorTimeLimit": 5000
}

允许生成器最多 5 秒来创建每个测试用例。

docs.title: cph-ng.bfCompare.bruteForceTimeLimit
docs.text:
允许暴力解法运行的最长时间（以毫秒为单位）。

  • 类型：数字
  • 默认值：10000（10 秒）
  • 用户影响：如果暴力解法运行时间超过此值，它将被终止。暴力解法通常很慢，因此这通常高于正常时间限制。

示例： 

{
  "cph-ng.bfCompare.bruteForceTimeLimit": 30000
}

允许暴力解法每个测试用例最多 30 秒。

docs.title: 工作原理
docs.text:
1. 生成器执行：创建随机测试输入（受 generatorTimeLimit 限制）
  2. 您的解法：在生成的输入上运行（使用题目的时间限制）
  3. 暴力解法：在相同输入上运行（受 bruteForceTimeLimit 限制）
  4. 比较：比较输出
  5. 结果：
  6. 如果输出匹配：尝试另一个测试用例
  7. 如果输出不同：找到失败用例！ 保存以供调试

docs.title: 磁盘操作
docs.text:
找到失败的测试用例时：

  1. 保存输入：生成的输入作为新测试用例保存到磁盘
  2. 您的输出：记录您的解法的输出
  3. 预期输出：暴力解法的输出成为预期答案
  4. 更新题目：新测试用例添加到题目文件
  5. 更新文件：题目数据文件（.cph-ng/*.bin）使用新测试用例更新

docs.title: 何时调整这些设置
docs.text:
何时增加 generatorTimeLimit： - 生成器创建复杂结构（图、树） - 生成器验证约束 - 在生成期间收到超时错误

何时增加 bruteForceTimeLimit： - 暴力解法具有高复杂度（O(n³)、O(2ⁿ)） - 使用大输入测试 - 在正确的暴力解法上收到超时

何时减少超时： - 想要更快的迭代（每分钟测试更多用例） - 生成器和暴力解法非常快 - 处理小输入

docs.title: 简单题目
docs.text:
{
  "cph-ng.bfCompare.generatorTimeLimit": 1000,
  "cph-ng.bfCompare.bruteForceTimeLimit": 5000
}

docs.title: 复杂题目
docs.text:
{
  "cph-ng.bfCompare.generatorTimeLimit": 10000,
  "cph-ng.bfCompare.bruteForceTimeLimit": 60000
}

docs.title: 相关功能
docs.text:
• 暴力对拍 - 主要功能文档
  • 添加测试用例 - 找到的用例保存位置
  • 运行器设置 - 您的解法使用标准运行器设置

docs.title: 缓存设置
docs.text: 控制编译缓存以加速重复编译的设置。

docs.title: cph-ng.cache.enabled
docs.text:
• 类型：布尔值
  • 默认值：true
  • 用户影响：启用时，编译的二进制文件被缓存。如果源代码和编译器设置未更改，则重用缓存的二进制文件，大大加快测试运行速度。

示例： 

{
  "cph-ng.cache.enabled": false
}

docs.title: cph-ng.cache.maxSize
docs.text:
• 类型：数字
  • 默认值：100（MB）
  • 用户影响：缓存可以使用的最大磁盘空间。超过时，删除最旧的条目。

示例： 

{
  "cph-ng.cache.maxSize": 200
}

docs.title: 工作原理
docs.text: 编译时： 1. 计算源代码和编译器设置的哈希值 2. 检查缓存中是否存在匹配的二进制文件 3. 如果找到且有效：使用缓存的二进制文件（非常快） 4. 如果未找到：编译并将结果存储在缓存中

docs.title: 磁盘操作
docs.text: 缓存文件存储在： - 位置：.cph-ng/cache/ 文件夹 - 文件名：基于源和设置的哈希值 - 大小：受 maxSize 限制 - 清理：超过限制时自动删除旧条目

docs.title: 何时禁用缓存
docs.text:
• 调试编译器问题
  • 测试不同的编译器设置
  • 磁盘空间有限

docs.title: 相关功能
docs.text:
• 编译设置 - 影响缓存键
  • 运行单个测试 - 使用缓存加速

docs.title: Companion 设置
docs.text: Competitive Companion 浏览器扩展集成的设置。

docs.title: cph-ng.companion.listenPort
docs.text:
• 类型：数字
  • 默认值：27121
  • 用户影响：CPH-NG 监听来自浏览器扩展的连接的端口。必须与 Competitive Companion 配置匹配。

docs.title: cph-ng.companion.defaultExtension
docs.text:
• 类型：字符串
  • 默认值：".cpp"
  • 用户影响：从浏览器导入题目时创建的文件扩展名。

docs.title: cph-ng.companion.shortCodeforcesName
docs.text:
• 类型：布尔值
  • 默认值：true
  • 用户影响：使用短题目名称（A、B、C）而不是完整标题用于 Codeforces。

docs.title: cph-ng.companion.shortLuoguName
docs.text:
• 类型：布尔值
  • 默认值：true
  • 用户影响：缩短洛谷题目名称。

docs.title: cph-ng.companion.shortAtCoderName
docs.text:
• 类型：布尔值
  • 默认值：true
  • 用户影响：缩短 AtCoder 题目名称。

docs.title: cph-ng.companion.chooseSaveFolder
docs.text:
• 类型：布尔值
  • 默认值：false
  • 用户影响：导入题目时是否提示选择保存位置。

docs.title: cph-ng.companion.showPanel
docs.text:
• 类型：数字（枚举）
  • 默认值：0
  • 用户影响：控制题目来源文件面板的可见性。

docs.title: cph-ng.companion.addTimestamp
docs.text:
• 类型：数字（枚举）
  • 默认值：0
  • 用户影响：是否在文件名中添加时间戳。

docs.title: cph-ng.companion.submitLanguage
docs.text:
• 类型：数字（枚举）
  • 默认值：根据评测而定
  • 用户影响：提交到 Codeforces 时使用的编译器版本。

docs.title: 工作原理
docs.text: 使用 Competitive Companion 时： 1. 在评测网站上点击浏览器扩展图标 2. 扩展向 listenPort 发送题目数据 3. CPH-NG 接收题目元数据和测试用例 4. 创建具有 defaultExtension 的新文件 5. 题目数据保存在 .cph-ng/ 中

docs.title: 磁盘操作
docs.text: 导入题目时创建： - 源文件：在工作区根或选定文件夹中 - 题目数据：.cph-ng/{filename}.bin - 测试用例：内联或外部文件

docs.title: 相关功能
docs.text:
• Competitive Companion - 主要功能文档
  • 提交到 Codeforces - 使用 submitLanguage

docs.title: 比较设置
docs.text: 控制测试输出如何与预期答案进行比较的设置。

docs.title: cph-ng.comparing.oleSize
docs.text:
检测输出超限的阈值（以行为单位）。

  • 类型：数字
  • 默认值：3
  • 用户影响：如果实际输出与预期答案相比有超过这么多额外行，判决将变为 OLE（输出超限）而不是 WA（答案错误）。

示例： 

{
  "cph-ng.comparing.oleSize": 5
}

有 6+ 额外行的输出获得 OLE 而不是 WA。

docs.title: cph-ng.comparing.regardPEAsAC
docs.text:
将格式错误（尾随/前导空白差异）视为接受。

  • 类型：布尔值
  • 默认值：false
  • 用户影响：
  • false：行尾额外空白或额外空行导致 PE 判决
  • true：忽略空白差异，判决变为 AC

示例： 

{
  "cph-ng.comparing.regardPEAsAC": true
}

尾随空格和额外空行不会导致 PE 判决。

竞技编程

大多数在线评测对空白宽容。将此设置为 true 匹配典型评测行为。

docs.title: cph-ng.comparing.ignoreError
docs.text:
控制在判决中是否考虑 stderr 输出。

  • 类型：布尔值
  • 默认值：true
  • 用户影响：
  • true：程序可以写入 stderr 而不影响判决（调试输出常见）
  • false：任何 stderr 输出导致不同判决或警告

示例： 

{
  "cph-ng.comparing.ignoreError": false
}

写入 stderr 的程序将被标记。

调试输出

保持此为 true 允许在 C++ 中使用 cerr 进行调试而不影响正确性检查。

docs.title: 比较行为
docs.text:
比较过程如下：

  1. 精确匹配：输出完全匹配答案 → AC（接受）
  2. 空白差异：尾随/前导空格不同 → PE（格式错误），或如果 regardPEAsAC 为 true 则为 AC
  3. 内容错误：输出内容不同 → WA（答案错误）
  4. 输出过多：超过 oleSize 额外行 → OLE（输出超限）
  5. 运行时错误：程序崩溃或返回非零退出代码 → RE（运行时错误）
  6. 时间限制：执行超过时间限制 → TLE（超时）
  7. 内存限制：内存使用超过限制（如果启用运行器）→ MLE（内存超限）

docs.title: 何时更改这些设置
docs.text:
将 regardPEAsAC 设置为 true： - 为忽略空白的在线评测做准备 - 不想担心输出格式 - 专注于算法正确性

将 regardPEAsAC 设置为 false： - 需要精确的输出格式匹配 - 测试输出格式要求 - 为严格格式比赛做准备

将 ignoreError 设置为 false： - 调试不应写入 stderr 的程序 - 想要捕获所有诊断输出 - 测试代码质量

调整 oleSize： - 收到不正确的 OLE 判决 - 想要更严格或更宽松的检测

docs.title: 相关功能
docs.text:
• 比较输出 - WA/PE 情况的可视化差异
  • 运行单个测试 - 使用这些比较规则
  • 运行所有测试 - 应用于所有测试比较
  • 特殊评测 - 覆盖标准比较

docs.title: 编译设置
docs.text: 控制 CPH-NG 如何为 C、C++ 和 Java 编译源代码的设置。

docs.title: cph-ng.compilation.cPath
docs.text:
• 类型：字符串（可执行文件路径）
  • 默认值："gcc"
  • 用户影响：指定要使用的 C 编译器。必须在系统 PATH 中可访问或提供完整路径。

docs.title: cph-ng.compilation.cppPath
docs.text:
• 类型：字符串（可执行文件路径）
  • 默认值："g++"
  • 用户影响：指定要使用的 C++ 编译器。

docs.title: cph-ng.compilation.javaPath
docs.text:
• 类型：字符串（可执行文件路径）
  • 默认值："javac"
  • 用户影响：指定要使用的 Java 编译器。

docs.title: cph-ng.compilation.cArgs
docs.text:
• 类型：字符串
  • 默认值："-O2 -std=gnu11 -Wall"
  • 用户影响：控制优化级别、语言标准和警告。

docs.title: cph-ng.compilation.cppArgs
docs.text:
• 类型：字符串
  • 默认值："-O2 -std=gnu++20 -Wall"
  • 用户影响：C++ 编译器的额外参数。

docs.title: cph-ng.compilation.javaArgs
docs.text:
• 类型：字符串
  • 默认值：""
  • 用户影响：Java 编译器的额外参数。

docs.title: cph-ng.compilation.timeout
docs.text:
• 类型：数字
  • 默认值：5000（5 秒）
  • 用户影响：编译超过此时间终止。增加用于大项目。

docs.title: 磁盘操作
docs.text: 编译的二进制文件存储在： - C/C++：临时缓存目录中的可执行文件 - Java：.class 文件在源文件旁边 - 使用缓存时，二进制文件在 .cph-ng/cache/ 中

docs.title: 相关功能
docs.text:
• 运行单个测试 - 在运行前编译
  • 缓存设置 - 加速编译

docs.title: CPH 兼容性设置
docs.text: 与原始 CPH 扩展集成的设置。

docs.title: cph-ng.cphCapable.enabled
docs.text:
• 类型：布尔值
  • 默认值：true
  • 用户影响：启用时，CPH-NG 检查 CPH 题目文件并允许导入它们。

docs.title: cph-ng.cphCapable.checkInterval
docs.text:
• 类型：数字
  • 默认值：500（毫秒）
  • 用户影响：检查 CPH 题目文件存在性的频率。

docs.title: 工作原理
docs.text: 启用 CPH 兼容性时： 1. CPH-NG 监视 CPH 题目文件（.cph/ 文件夹） 2. 如果检测到 CPH 题目，显示导入按钮 3. 用户可以将 CPH 题目转换为 CPH-NG 格式 4. 转换保留所有测试用例和元数据

docs.title: 磁盘操作
docs.text: CPH 文件位置： - 原始：.cph/{filename}.prob - 检测：定期检查此位置 - 导入：转换为 CPH-NG 格式 - 保存：在 .cph-ng/ 中的新格式

docs.title: 何时禁用
docs.text:
• 不使用原始 CPH
  • 减少后台检查
  • 性能原因

docs.title: 相关功能
docs.text:
• 导入题目 - 单个 CPH 题目导入
  • CPH 导入 - 批量 CPH 导入
